results.description:
Professional Business Networking Event in Elmhurst, Queens.

BNI Dream Team As a reminder here's why we wake up early Tuesday mornings. 98% of businesses rely on referrals to build new business. ONLY 3% of businesses have a strategy to generate those referrals. Our BNI networking meetings are a proven word of mouth marketing referral generating strategy. Last year, members of BNI (Business Networking International) passed millions of referrals that generated billions of dollars of business for each other. Belonging to BNI is like having dozens of salespeople representing your business, and in return you are representing their businesses. What goes around comes around. If I help you, you’ll help me and we will both benefit as a result.

Here are the details for our next meeting Tuesday, June 9th 2015

The meeting starts at 7:00AM and is officially over at 8:30AM

results.description:
Come join us for an invigorating breakfast and networking event.

There will be at least 15 members at each meeting, regardless of how many people RSVP on Meetup.

Meet successful business owners from different professions to give and pass referrals and grow your personal network.

BNI, the largest business networking organization in the world, is a business and professional referral organization that allows only one person from each profession to join a chapter.  Belonging to BNI is like having dozens of sales people working for you because all the other members carry several copies of your business cards around with them. When they meet someone who could use your products or services they hand your card out and recommend your services. It's as simple as that!  

For 28 years BNI has used a simple but elegant philosophy that exemplifies membership, "Givers Gain," or, "what goes around comes around."

 Last year alone, Business Network Int'l generated over 7.1 million referrals resulting in more than $3.3 billion worth of business for its members!

In Manhattan, BNI currently has more than 1250 members in 53 Chapters. 

BRING LOTS OF BUSINESS CARDS!!!
Cost is $20, which includes breakfast.

results.description:
In this FREE workshop training, Java Champion Trisha Gee teaches you how to build a Java 8 application end-to-end. The tutorial utilizes live code demonstration to build a fully functional application using minimal external dependencies and Java 8. This application consumes a real-time feed of high velocity data, contains services that make sense of the data, and presents it in a JavaFX dashboard. Along the way, you’ll encounter Java 8 streams, lambdas, new ways of working with collections, and the new date and time API.

What We’ll Cover:

- Sort messages containing information about users to create a leaderboard of the most active Twitter users

- Consume messages about tweet sentiment to create a pie chart that updates in real time to show overall mood on Twitter

- Filter sentiment messages to create a view of happiness levels over a ten minute period

- Build a microservice that parses a file of real Twitter data and publishes these Tweets via web sockets

- Build a microservice that parses Twitter messages and emits just the username

- Build a microservice that analyses Twitter messages for sentiment and publishes these moods

- Connect the application to a live Twitter feed

Pre-requisites:

- Working knowledge of the Java programming language

- Experienced Java developers familiar with Java 7 looking to learn Java 8

Requirements:

Bring your laptop for hands-on exercises with sample code. Sample code will be provided to attendees for download ahead of the workshop.

Your Instructor:

Trisha Gee, Java Champion, has developed Java applications for a range of industries, including finance, manufacturing, technology, open source, and non-profit, for companies of all sizes. She has expertise in Java high-performance systems, and is passionate about enabling developer productivity. Trisha blogs regularly on subjects developers and other humans should care about, she’s a leader of the Sevilla Java User Group, and a key member of the Java Community. She believes we shouldn't all have to make the same mistakes again and again.

**Seating is limited to the first 40 respondents.**

This event will be recorded. Attendees MUST sign a release in order to participate. If you would like to see a copy of the release before the event, contact the event organizer.

Security for Building Access:

To enter the building, you MUST provide your full name to the community team putting on this event. Once registered, email julie (dot) phifer (at) pearson (dot) com with your full name and the name of your guest (if applicable). If you fail to provide this information, you will not be allowed in the building. Please bring an ID to sign into the 330 Hudson St. building.

Directions:

Visit Google Maps for directions to building.
results.name: Building Java 8 Web Applications with Microservices (One-Day Workshop)

Every Tuesday the CHA will meet at 12pm at the NY Hilton hotel. The Cannabis and Hemp Association can only accept CHA Affiliates who RSVP to the event. If you wish to attend a Meetup and bring a friend, they must become a CHA Affiliate. Your friend's or collegues may become an affiliate by joining the group www.meetup.com/cannabisandhemp . Here the CHA will discuss membership benefits, offer free consultations to anyone interested in the cannabis industry, and have an open forum to discuss future Meetups and CHA monthly events.

At the Meetup, the CHA often provides written materials for the lecture. Only those who RSVP will receive a copy of the meeting notes. Our materials are distributed based on those who have RSVP'd only.

Cannabis and Hemp TV is an online video blog where specific topics in  the cannabis industry are discussed, analyzed, and broken down amongst a panel.  All observers are welcome. Please RSVP and unRSVP if you cannot attend.

The NY Hilton is free to all members of the group and members are encouraged to bring friends, business ideas, business cards, and anything they would like to discuss about all things cannabis.

results.description:
I give a 'free', forever ongoing, astronomy class at the Senior Center.  You don't have to be a senior to join, but you must join the Senior Center for $72/year, which you can defer for at least a month, until you determine that you want to continue.

I never give the same lecture twice.  It would bore me.  My lectures are well prepared, and contain enormous resources from the live web, projected from my laptop to a flat screen TV.  It's all about gaining a perspective of your/my place in the universe.

==================

The class meets Tuesdays at 12:45pm.  Just come.  241 W 72st.  Ask for Laird.  (As of August, 2014, as well as for the last 5 years.)

To make sure the class isn't cancelled (it normally meets every week of the year), please email me at laird wh (one word) at aol dot com.  Make sure the word MEETUP does NOT appear anywhere in the email.  (It gets sorted away from my inbox.)
results.why: Astronomy is about EVERYTHING.  Or at least thats why I became interested in it in 2nd grade.  Now, 40 years post Ph.D. in Astronomy, Astronomy, and indeed all of science is still my passion.   My advisor was Carl Sagan.

results.description:
THE YORK THEATRE COMPANY

 

DEVELOPMENTAL READINGS SERIES

FREE but you need to make a reservation (look below)

 

 

Juliet and Juliet

Tuesday, June 9th - 2:00PM

Based on a concept by Natalie Tenenbaum and Sean Patterson

Book & Lyrics: Sean Patterson

Music and Music Direction: Natalie Tenenbaum

Director: Ilana Ransom Toeplitz

Produced by Three Ways A MongIII LLC

Stage manager: Shelley Miles

 

ASM: Hollace Jeffords

JULIET & JULIET is the story of senior Tommie Morgan, who has her heart set on a big fat lead role in Verona High's production of Romeo and Juliet . Her hopes are dashed, though, when homecoming queen Caroline Pelletti is pre-cast as Juliet, as a result of nasty PTA politics. So Tommie settles for the next best thing: she disguises herself as a boy and auditions for Romeo instead. She expects people to be shocked, but she doesn't expect to fall in love.

CAST LIST:

Chris Kogler is a business story strategist. He teaches people from all walks of life to harness the power and science of stories to increase the sales of their products and services. In this session Chris will discuss how photographers can use powerful, personal stories to stand out from the crowd and improve the sales of their photos and photographic services.


“Stories hold the power to transform listeners; to take listeners on a journey that changes how they think, feel and act.” Prof. Jennifer Aaker, Professor of Marketing, Stanford University

All in attendance will be given a coupon for $25 off your next purchase of $250.

This seminar will be two (2) sessions of ninety (90) minutes each

Adorama is located at 42 West 18th Street, NYC. We're just a short walk from Union Square or the 6th Avenue - 14th Street subway station.

Biography:

Chris Kogler is the CEO of Narrative IQ. He teaches business leaders to use personal business stories to increase sales, communicate more effectively and initiate & manage change - all of which have a common goal: to bring a company’s strategies to life.

Early in his career Chris worked in television as the Creative Director for Channel 13/WNET. During his 16 years at WNET, he developed his love of stories. His storytelling skills won him 5 Emmy Awards and his clients have included General Electric, General Motors, ABC and HBO.

Today, he’s Partners with the Australian consulting firm, Anecdote, and has 2 programs, Storytelling for Leaders and Storytelling for Sales, that he uses in his consulting practice to teach leaders The Power of Business Stories.


http://www.adorama.com/alc/sites/default/files/styles/bio_image/public/ChrisKogler_HEAD.jpg?itok=O87AhbK3

results.description:
This will be a double No Ad Round Robin. Winners will each receive Nike Rafa Hats.
Weather: Check back for any cancellations due to poor weather or otherwise.

Transit: 2 or 5 trains to E 174th St stop and short walk. 5 train runs express until 7PM from E 149th St-Third Ave to E 180th St. BX17, BX21 and BX11 within walking distance

• Court number/location will be announced in comments upon arrival.

Ready? Play.
_____________________________________________________

What will we be doing at the Meetup?
We will be meeting at the tennis courts for some friendly rallying, doubles, and singles play*. This meetup is open to players at any skill level; from beginner to advanced.

*For those of you who are interested in singles play, please keep in mind that the ability to play singles predicates on the amount of members who have RSVPed as well as court availability at the meetup event's venue. We cannot guarantee singles play in every instance.

How long will the meetup be?
The time listed for the meetup event is when you can expect to the event host to be there. If you would like to arrive earlier or later than the start time listed, please leave a comment in the meetup event you plan to attend. This will give everyone in attendance a good representation of who is showing up at what time.

What will it be like?
Our group is very friendly and loosely organized to allow for a fun experience.

Upon arrival, our event host will announce which court they are on in the comments of the meetup event. If you have a smartphone, we strongly suggest that you download the Meetup app for iPhone or Android to make communication easier.

When you arrive at the courts, look for the event host listed or other members of the group playing on (or near) the courts listed. Use the photos of each host/member on the website as a frame of reference.

Introduce yourself. Let the host know your level of play and you will be assigned to a court immediately.

Do members need to bring anything?
All members must bring their own racquet. Unfortunately, we do not supply racquets.

All members are encouraged to bring a fresh can of new balls. You can always use a marker to mark your initials on your ball if you would like to keep them for future play. Please keep in mind that tennis balls only last a couple of days after taking them out of the can before they lose their bounce.

If you plan to donate to the group, you can leave your donation with the meetup event host or the head organizer, Frank, if he’s in attendance. All donations go towards the fees required to organize the meetup.

Who should come? Are newcomers welcome?
Our meetup event is open to all players whether they're an absolute beginner or an advanced player. Players will be matched up with others based on their skill level. Beginners will be given an opportunity to play with higher level players so they can gain more experience with higher consistency.

It is a high priority for our group to help beginners increase their skill and become better players. If you are reading this and are an absolute beginner, please don't be intimidated. We want you to join us and have fun.

What should a newcomer expect?
If you're new to the group, you'll learn very quickly that our community is extremely friendly. We have a colorful cast of characters from all walks of life who are ready and willing to have a good time.

Whether you're interested in easy-going rallying or competitive play, we can accommodate you.

Questions?
If you have any other questions, concerns, or comments; please send them to our head organizer, Frank Tirado via email.

results.description:
Becoming a trader has numerous moving parts. Foremost is learning core principles that lead to trade-generating strategies and tactics. But that only gets you so far. Trades occur NOT in a vacuum, but in the CONTEXT of the trading environment at a specific time. The “trading weather” plays a key role in what works, how well, and when. For instance:

You can have the best trade set-up but the environment may conspire against it, suggesting that you either (a) take the trade at a reduced position size, or (b) don't take it at all, but rather, trade something else that's more advantageous under the circumstances. (c) The environment may suggest that you modify your tactics, i.e., entries/exits/stops, scaling-in, scaling-out tactics. Finally (d) you may identify an alternate way of expressing the trade, e.g., using options or futures rather than a particular stock

Join us as we discuss how to stack the deck and develop a consistent plan so you recognize when the environment is your ally, and when it's likely to turn against your trade. We'll talk about:

·  Having a premarket routine

·  Using and monitoring market bellwethers that “take the temperature” of the trading environment, both premarket and throughout the day

·  Understanding how the price action of what you trade changes over time, both intraday and in swing scenarios – should you aim to hit singles in a choppy market environment, or go for extra-base hits when the environment suggests you can reasonably expect follow-through on price action

·  Factoring key scheduled announcements into your data plan and how to intelligently modify your trade tactics to your benefit

· Developing a simple, objective way of assessing trend for your instrument, sectors and the broad market, and determining how they inter-relate/

This will be the "grand finale" wrap-up in our Spring series by Ryan and Mitch focused on trading on price action. You won't want to miss it!
results.name: Stack the Deck with a Trading Edge -- Understanding "Trading Weather"

results.description:
One day a year, nine of the city's finest museums, all ones that call Fifth Avenue home, collectively open their doors for free to New Yorkers and visitors for a mile-long block party and visual art celebration. 


Begun as an initiative to spur the development of new museum audiences and to increase support for the arts during the fiscal crisis of the 1970s, Museum Mile was formed as a consortium by the museums that share the Fifth Avenue address. The first festival, held in June of 1978, was an instant success. Not only did it expose New Yorkers and NYC visitors to an incredible collection of New York’s artistic riches, it also brought together disparate New Yorkers. From the barrios of East Harlem and the townhouses lining the Upper East Side, to the winding streets of the Village and the clustered neighborhoods of the outer-boroughs, people came to celebrate their shared pride in their city. Museum Mile Festival promoted public awareness through increased visibility, accessibility and attendance at all the museums, and brought many New Yorkers to upper Fifth Avenue for the first time.


This traffic-free, music and art-filled celebration fills the street and sidewalks of Fifth Avenue from 82nd to 105th Street, the mile now officially designated as Museum Mile. 

Visit 

www.museummilefestival.org.

In the past, we usually hit 4 museums...  so do come early. as the lines get longer and longer into the nite.

My recommendations:

86th Street and Fifth Avenue               Neue Galerie New York 

90th Street and Fifth Avenue               National Academy Museum Schl


92nd Street and Fifth Avenue               The Jewish Museum


104th Street and Fifth Avenue               El Museo del Barrio


103rd Street and Fifth Avenue                Museum of the City of New York


91st Street and Fifth Avenue                   Cooper Hewitt, Smithsonian  

Opening Ceremony 5:45pm @ Cooper

Please note that Guggenheim and Met are free on Fridays every week already.

See more at: http://museummilefestival.org/index.php/map-schedule#sthash.dHruM4NV.dpuf

results.description:
Mark your calendars for Tuesday, June 9th! We're in for a treat this month with a walking tour of all the changes happening in Hunter's Point South from meetup member Justin G. Moore, Senior Urban Designer, NYC Dept. of City Planning.


Just across the river from the UN, Hunter's Point South (in Long Island City) is one of NYC's most rapidly changing riverside landscapes. Come hear all about the sustainability aspects of the changes underfoot in the 30-acre development project to transform a formerly industrial waterfront into a mixed-use neighborhood.  The project began in 2006 and included new infrastructure, parks, affordable housing, and community and retail spaces.  

The short walking tour will begin at 50th Avenue and Center Boulevard (by the Gantries) and discussion of the projects will conclude in the outdoor space of at "LIC Bar" nearby (where you can join us if you miss the walking tour). 


***The Urban Sustainability Meetup group had so much fun with the Energy and Environment Happy Hour folks at our joint + POOL talk and happy hour that we're going to co-organize with them again for this event***    

Tour Meeting Location: Meet at 5:45 at 50th Avenue and Center Boulevard (by the Gantries) - take the 7 train to Vernon-Jackson (first stop in Queens).  At 6:00 sharp, we'll walk south from there for a short tour ~25 minutes, then we'll end at the nearby "LIC Bar" at 4558 Vernon Blvd; Long Island City, NY 11101 (46th Ave and Vernon) where you can join us at 6:30 if you miss the tour, we have the outdoor space reserved!
results.how_to_find_us: 50th Avenue and Center Boulevard (by the Gantries) - (take the Vernon-Jackson 7 train stop, and walk two block west)
results.name: Walking tour of Hunter's Point South (ending with drinks)

results.description: The Microsoft Conference Center, is free of charge. Ignore the note on this page, which says, "Max: 1 person". We never max out room capacity. The reason it says it's maxed out, is because I can't sign you up through meetup.com. To RSVP, please send an email to alfred dot vachris at gmail dot com, with your first and last name. A photo ID is mandatory. You will receive an email once a month from the Microsoft Organizer. We plan on meeting on the 2nd Tuesday of every month, but there are changes occasionally. You should receive an email, if there's a cancellation. The Conference Center's security department, requires your first and last name, so please include your full name, within the body of your email. Sometimes, the map on this meetup link above, is incorrect, so please write down the address, (at 41st Street and 8th Avenue, NorthEast corner... i.e. not in Port Authority). If you don't get an email back from anyone, within a day or two, please send a 2nd request. I always learn something new at the group, like an advanced feature, or a glitch/bug to beware of. For example, did you know that formulas entered in the Named Range box calculate as "Array Entered". It's OK, to arrive half an hour early and use the free coffee machine. Try to go early, if it's your first time, in case you are not registered properly. If you arrive, and the the security personnel informs you of a registration problem, don't be alarmed, they will assist you. Please be patient. This event is scheduled for 5:45 PM and 6:00 PM. See link below. After you receive an email from the Microsoft Organizer, stating we will meet on this date, you may sign up for the 6:00 PM event, (no seating limitation, but the security desk closes a little after 7:00 PM). http://www.meetup.com/Spreadsheets/events/calendar/

Movie is Spy, 8pm showing I have seat D8, 2 for $20 dinner at Broad Street Diner at 6pm

Ok who LOVES the movies as much as me? Who has a limited entertainment budget like me? LOL Well this is the event for YOU!

My local theater has discount Tuesday every week and if you sign up online they will even send you a coupon for the concession stand, each week a different one (this weeks is free small popcorn with a drink purchase). They also have those awesome new reclining seats! And you get to choose and pay for your seat in advance so there is no rushing in at the last minute and sitting in the front row and straining your neck!  Here is the link to the theater for more details: http://www.cinemark.com/theatre-detail.aspx?node_id=83854

So here is how it's going to work each week. I will choose a movie when the new schedule goes out (Thur/Fri) and choose the movie and showtime. I will buy my seat online and post what row and number. Those of you who wish to join me can buy your seat near me. There are two ways to buy seats: 1) online in advance is your best bet but there is a $1.25 service fee per ticket 2) At the theater no service fee but you really need to driver there in advance if you want seats near us. OR you can just show up that night and sit wherever there is space available.

If anyone wants to host dinner beforehand please post and say so, The Red Oak diner is nearby, fast, has something for every taste and budget, and will gladly give you separate checks. I will come for dinner IF I can make it but can't promise due to work schedule. https://www.redoakdiner.com/online/ Hope to see YOU at the movies!!  Love, Cassie

if you can't make it, no need to post why. We understand and will catch you next time!

Also if time allows those who wish we can go to The Broad Street Diner in Keyport for dinner before the show they have a great two for $20 special

results.description:
Join us for Wristware where we'll head to Mashable HQ to discuss what's next in smartwatches, wearables and IOT. We're featuring a dynamic thought-leadership panel focused on design, UX, apps, trends and state of the industry. Cocktail networking and appetizers will follow the panel.  

We're giving early bird summer tix here, so grab yours soon. 

Agenda

6:00 - 6:45   Doors Open, Arrive & Mingle

6:45 - 7:00   Welcome Remarks and Intros 

7:00 - 8:00   Leadership Panel, Q & A

8:00 - 9:00   Cocktail Networking

Moderator:

Paul Farkas, CEO, Co-Founder, Accessory2

Leadership Panel:

Ali Hussain, SVP Customer Experience, Citi

Marc Rabinowitz, Senior UX, Code & Theory

Sree Sreenivasan, Chief Digital Officer, Metropolitan Museum of Art

Amy Puliafito, Director of Communications, Misfit

Tat Wza, Co-Founder/Manager, InFlexWeTrust.com; Producer,Funk Flex Show!; Emmis Communications


#SmartwatchNYC | #Wristware | #OneNYC


Produced and Hosted by Accessory2, a fashion and wearable lifestyle creative house and consultancy, co-founded by Paul Farkas and Kimmie Smith. http://Accessory2.com/

@Accessory_2 | @WearableMedia | @AccessoryExpert


Some more about this session's speakers:

Marc Rabinowitz, Senior UX, Code & Theory

Marc Rabinowitz is a Senior UX Designer at Code and Theory, where he champions and leads cross-platform UI/Product Design initiatives for Huffington Post and Comcast.

Prior to Code and Theory, his work for clients including ESPN The Magazine, New York City Ballet, Live Nation, Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, Alliance Bernstein, American Airlines, UL,  and Inc. Magazine exhibited a seamless mix of print, web, interactive, motion graphics, environmental and digital product design. 

Marc's work has been awarded by AIGA, the Art Director's Club, and the Adobe Design Achievement Awards, and published by Design Observer, Life Hacker and Rockport Publishers, among others. Marc received his MFA in Design Entrepreneurship from the School of Visual Arts in 2008.

Amy Puliafito, Director of Communications, Misfit

Amy is Director of Communications for Misfit. Before, she lead research, social media, and marketing at Rock Health. Previously, she worked for the Keck School of Medicine of USC and Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School for Public Health, and was in charge of fundraising at a non-profit that led international training trips for physicians in Mongolia and China. She has a BA in sociology.

Sree Sreenivasan, Chief Digital Officer, Metropolitan Museum of Art           

Sree Sreenivasan (@sree) is the first Chief Digital Officer at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the latest step in what he calls "a three-decade, one-way love affair with one of the world's great museums." He joined the Met after spending 20 years at Columbia University as a member of the faculty of the Columbia Journalism School and a year as the university's first Chief Digital Officer.

In 2015, he was named to Fast Company's list of 100 Most Creative People in Business, in part for the work he and the museum are doing on the future of culture: http://bit.ly/sreefc ; 
In 2009, he was named one of AdAge's 25 media people to follow on Twitter and in 2010 was named one of Poynter's the 35 most influential people in social media; in 2014, he was named the most influential CDO in the US. 

NYT: Museums See Different Virtues in Virtual Museums http://www.nytimes.com/2014/08/08/arts/design/museums-see-different-virtues-in-virtual-worlds.html?_r=1


Tat Wza, Co-Founder, Manager, InFlexWeTrust.com; Associate Producer, Funk Flex Show!, Emmis Communications

Tat has been rocking with WQHT Hot 97 since 1997, now Producer of the Funk Flex Show! Tat partnered with Flex in 2010, starting InFlexWeTrust.com which he now manages. InFlexWeTrust.com (IFWT) one of the biggest Hip Hop sites In the world. Tat is currently also a Digital Producer for Hot97.com, Flex's blog page, and produces a monthly gaming event with Rockstar Games for GTAV, and Max Payne.

Tat also writes a tech article for urban men's magazine Straight Stuntin, and manges other digital properties like the Dj Funk Flex App, StunnaLife.com and Digital Director for Planet Kixx.

We work hard to guarantee the quality of our membership is for genuine women entrepreneurs who come together to practice Give, Give, Get through our signature mastermind sessions. If you are a serious woman entrepreneur we would love to meet you and get to know you and your business better!

Note: Savor the Success is a Women's Network, therefore only women are allowed to join and attend our live events.

Space is limited so RSVP by clicking here (do not RSVP through Meetup).


* * * * * *

Savor Sisters! Join us for drinks at 5:30 before the event to connect and meet new faces. We'll see you in the Madison Lounge off the lobby.

* * * * * *

Do you believe that women can “have it all,” or do you think that you need to make big sacrifices in order to succeed in business? 

At this special LIVE Mastermind Presentation, featured expert Laura Vanderkam will reveal what she learned from six-figure women who feel they've cracked the code on having it all. She'll share how they make time for work, home, fun (and sleep!), and how you can too.

During this presentation, you will learn how to:

• Track your time and make the most out of the 168 hours that everyone has

• Schedule time for what matters: advance your business, enjoy family activities, AND pursue your passions

• Identify success habits and weed out self-sabotage

• Truly have it all!

Space is limited so RSVP by clicking here (do not RSVP through Meetup). 

If you're attending for the first time, receive a FREE TRIAL membership and attend the meeting at no cost!

Laura Vanderkam is the author of the forthcoming book I Know How She Does It: How Successful Women Build Lives That Work. She is a frequent contributor to Fast Company’s website and a member of USA Today’s Board of Contributors. Her work has appeared in numerous publications including The Wall Street Journal, The New York Times, Reader’s Digest, City Journal, Fortune, and Prevention. Laura has appeared on television programs, including The Today Show and Fox & Friends, and hundreds of radio segments, and speaks regularly about time, money, and productivity. She blogs daily at LauraVanderkam.com.

* * * * * *

Give, Give, Get Masterminding Sessions

Our expert presentation will be followed by our signature "Give, Give, Get" Mastermind break-out sessions. Join with your Savor Sisters, other women entrepreneurs and business leaders to give, and receive, 7-8 minutes of the group "think-tanking" on YOUR behalf!

Savor the Success LIVE events are for women entrepreneurs and women business leaders. If you are not currently a member, please use these instructions to receive a FREE TRIAL membership and attend the meeting at no cost!

Space is limited so RSVP by clicking here (do not RSVP through Meetup).

Be SURE to RSVP because we do sell out quickly and we don't want to turn you away!

results.description:
One day a year, nine of the city's finest museums, all ones that call Fifth Avenue home, collectively open their doors for free to New Yorkers and visitors for a mile-long block party and visual art celebration. Begun as an initiative to spur the development of new museum audiences and to increase support for the arts during the fiscal crisis of the 1970s, Museum Mile was formed as a consortium by the museums that share the Fifth Avenue address. The first festival, held in June of 1978, was an instant success. Not only did it expose New Yorkers and NYC visitors to an incredible collection of New York’s artistic riches, it also brought together disparate New Yorkers. From the barrios of East Harlem and the townhouses lining the Upper East Side, to the winding streets of the Village and the clustered neighborhoods of the outer-boroughs, people came to celebrate their shared pride in their city. Museum Mile Festival promoted public awareness through increased visibility, accessibility and attendance at all the museums, and brought many New Yorkers to upper Fifth Avenue for the first time.

This traffic-free, music and art-filled celebration fills the street and sidewalks of Fifth Avenue from 82nd to 105th Street, the mile now officially designated as Museum Mile. Visit www.museummilefestival.org.
results.name: Museum Mile

results.description:
Join us for Wristware where we'll head to Mashable HQ to discuss what's next in smartwatches, wearables and IOT. We're featuring a dynamic thought-leadership panel focused on design, UX, apps, trends and state of the industry. Cocktail networking and appetizers will follow the panel.  

We're giving early bird summer tix here, so grab your tickets soon. 

Agenda

6:00 - 6:45   Doors Open, Arrive & Mingle

6:45 - 7:00   Welcome Remarks and Intros 

7:00 - 8:00   Leadership Panel, Q & A

8:00 - 9:00   Cocktail Networking

Moderator:

Paul Farkas, CEO, Co-Founder, Accessory2

Leadership Panel:

Ali Hussain, SVP Customer Experience, Citi

Marc Rabinowitz, Senior UX, Code & Theory

Sree Sreenivasan, Chief Digital Officer, Metropolitan Museum of Art

Amy Puliafito, Director of Communications, Misfit

Tat Wza, Co-Founder/Manager, InFlexWeTrust.com; Producer, Funk Flex Show!; Emmis Communications

#SmartwatchNYC | #Wristware | #OneNYC

Produced and Hosted by Accessory2, a fashion and wearable lifestyle creative house and consultancy, co-founded by Paul Farkas and Kimmie Smith. http://Accessory2.com/ @Accessory_2 | @WearableMedia | @AccessoryExpert

Some more about this session's speakers:

Marc Rabinowitz, Senior UX, Code & Theory

Marc Rabinowitz is a Senior UX Designer at Code and Theory, where he champions and leads cross-platform UI/Product Design initiatives for Huffington Post and Comcast.

Prior to Code and Theory, his work for clients including ESPN The Magazine, New York City Ballet, Live Nation, Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, Alliance Bernstein, American Airlines, UL,  and Inc. Magazine exhibited a seamless mix of print, web, interactive, motion graphics, environmental and digital product design. 

Marc's work has been awarded by AIGA, the Art Director's Club, and the Adobe Design Achievement Awards, and published by Design Observer, Life Hacker and Rockport Publishers, among others. Marc received his MFA in Design Entrepreneurship from the School of Visual Arts in 2008.

Amy Puliafito, Director of Communications, Misfit

Amy is Director of Communications for Misfit. Before, she lead research, social media, and marketing at Rock Health. Previously, she worked for the Keck School of Medicine of USC and Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School for Public Health, and was in charge of fundraising at a non-profit that led international training trips for physicians in Mongolia and China. She has a BA in sociology.

Sree Sreenivasan, Chief Digital Officer, Metropolitan Museum of Art            

Sree Sreenivasan (@sree) is the first Chief Digital Officer at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the latest step in what he calls "a three-decade, one-way love affair with one of the world's great museums." He joined the Met after spending 20 years at Columbia University as a member of the faculty of the Columbia Journalism School and a year as the university's first Chief Digital Officer.

In 2015, he was named to Fast Company's list of 100 Most Creative People in Business, in part for the work he and the museum are doing on the future of culture: http://bit.ly/sreefc 
In 2009, he was named one of AdAge's 25 media people to follow on Twitter and in 2010 was named one of Poynter's the 35 most influential people in social media; in 2014, he was named the most influential CDO in the US. 

NYT: Museums See Different Virtues in Virtual Museums http://www.nytimes.com/2014/08/08/arts/design/museums-see-different-virtues-in-virtual-worlds.html?_r=1


Tat Wza, Co-Founder, Manager, InFlexWeTrust.com; Associate Producer, Funk Flex Show!, Emmis Communications

Tat has been rocking with WQHT Hot 97 since 1997, now Producer of the Funk Flex Show! Tat partnered with Flex in 2010, starting InFlexWeTrust.com which he now manages. InFlexWeTrust.com (IFWT) one of the biggest Hip Hop sites In the world. Tat is currently also a Digital Producer for Hot97.com, Flex's blog page, and produces a monthly gaming event with Rockstar Games for GTAV, and Max Payne.

Tat also writes a tech article for urban men's magazine Straight Stuntin, and manges other digital properties like the Dj Funk Flex App, StunnaLife.com and Digital Director for Planet Kixx.

results.description:
It's time to get kicking. Kick your neighbor. Kick your brother. Kick the big red ball. Just don't kick your dog. Game. On.

If you don't know, now you know ...

If you've never played the game of kickball as a kid you must have grown up on Mars. But as a quick primer, it's a game with rules similar to baseball -- except instead of using a bat to hit a little ball, you use your feet to kick a ball about 10x the size of a baseball. Kick the ball, run to the base, avoid getting your ball caught mid-air or yourself tagged out. Easy. And no athletic skill is necessary, just the ability to kick! Go out and practice now to get ready. Kick the postman when he delivers your bills. Kick that neighbor who won't turn down his stereo. Just get kicking!

If you haven't played the game in 20 years, here are the general rules we will be using https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/64476072/Kickball%20Rules.pdf.</a>

A $3.00 organization fee will be collected at this event, your host is in the running for hardest working person on meetup.

The important stuff ...

• This is a co-ed game so ladies don't be shy to sign up. And it doesn't matter if you have no athletic ability, you just have to be willing to have a little fun.

• Dress for physical activity! You'll be kicking and running so wear your sneaks, shorts and a t-shirt.

• Rain or similar un-favorable weather cancels the meetup. Not!

• Check the meetup site before leaving for last minute updates as well as my mobile phone number.

• Please DO NOT RSVP if you do not seriously plan to attend as space is limited. No flakes allowed! If you RSVP and I notice that you have a number of no shows or have a history of last minute cancellations, you will be removed.

• Sorry, no guests allowed for this one.

results.description:
****** MEETING HAS BEEN CANCELLED. NO MEETING IN JUNE. ******

RSVP: by day of meeting at 1pm.

Topic: Office 365 Administration for Exchange Admins


Meeting Abstract: Exchange Online (O365) Administration and Exchange Private Cloud (aka On-Premise) for Exchange administrators and introduction to managing Office 365 / Hybrid configurations. We will explore what it needs to become a champion in both worlds.


Speaker: Adnan Rafique


Speaker Bio: Adnan is a subject matter expert on Microsoft Exchange. He works as a Sr. Exchange Architect. He has been in the field of IT for more than 15 years and helped businesses with vertical implementations using state of the art Microsoft based solutions.  You can follow his blog www.ExchangeITpro.com and on Twitter @ExchangeITPro .

Where:

New Microsoft office. 11 Times Square, between 42nd & 41st on 8th Avenue. Located across from Port Authority.

Doors Open 5:45pm and dinner arrives at 6pm.


Please visit the official NYExUG website posting for full meeting details such as Speaker BIO's, Product details, and more.

You can reserve your seat via the official NYExUG website's meeting (www.nyexug.com)or meetup if you show/email your FULL NAME by 5pm on Monday before meeting. Free, Open to Public, and includes dinner.

Agenda

5:45pm - doors open/dinner arrives
6:30pm - presentation
8:30-9pm - raffle items

Folks attending will be able to win a various raffle items including Microsoft software. Free food, and open to all simply by RSVPing.

The meetings occur every 2nd Tuesday of every Month.

At our monthly meetings we have 1 or 2 main presentations covering various topics and discuss troubleshooting problems, adding new features and functionality, reviewing new products, and meeting/networking with other IT people (Exchange Admins, SysAdmins, IT Manager, IT Help Desk Support, CTOs, etc). Great way to learn about Microsoft Exchange Server in small, medium, and enterprise environments.

You can view past presentations on our website: nyexug.com

Past topics include: in-depth look at Microsoft's Redmond Dog-Food lab, live software replication demonstration, live hardware replication demonstration, Multi-site deployment recommendations, Configuring your firewall for Exchange 2003 and SP2 Changes (for the firewall), Moving your Exchange Server to a new Internet Connection, Groove, Exchange 2007, SAN Storage Solutions, Exchange Scaling Up, Server-side anti-spam solutions, Disaster Recovery, Outlook Direct Booking, Troubleshooting Exchange, Intro to Exchange and DNS, etc.

results.description:
EVENT TYPE: Dining

ADMISSION: You’ll need a referral for admission. Invitation only. 

DESCRIPTION:

Leave it to the Japanese to create a members-only bar that restores our flagging faith in hidden, members-only bars. Bohemian, the Noho sister of a bar in the Nishiazabu district of Tokyo, is tucked into the back of a building that used to belong to Andy Warhol. To reach the front door, you pass through a hallway dubbed “Basquiat Road” (the artist died in his loft at this address). Inside is an apartmentlike, low-ceilinged room containing just 25 plush seats, including a couple of couches and a six-seat yellow pine bar. The white-walled room is Zen simplicity, from the back bar made of tatami mats to a diorama-like mini Zen garden built into one wall to a central skylight that facilitates the art of “tsukimi sake” (moonlight boozin’). Bartenders serve a mix of signature and classic Asian and American cocktails, plying their craft with such precision that each time they present a drink, they shine a spotlight on it. Kiyo Shinoki, formerly the executive chef at Chanto, tells us Bohemian is more of a restaurant in the evening. He serves a mix of American, French, and Japanese small plates (everything from a burger with homemade pickles to short rib sashimi), and then later in the night, until 2am, the space takes on a lounge vibe, with bossa nova, jazz, and Japanese music. As with the Tokyo original that’s hidden behind a house, there isn’t any standing room, just seating at a row of low-to-the-ground two-tops and a couple of couches. In fact, Shinoki says he wants to maintain a maximum 60 percent capacity.

MENU:

• Dinner Menu 1

• Dinner Menu 2

RESTAURANT GALLERY:

• Inside the restaurant

• A hidden room inside the restaurant

• The Bar

FOOD GALLERY:

• Seafood Paella

• Branzino

• Oysters

• Washu Beef Short Rib Sashimi

• Uni Croquette.

• Beef Tarter Flatbread


RESTAURANT REVIEW:

• http://www.yelp.com/biz/bohemian-restaurant-new-York

• http://www.playearth.jp 

Disclaimer:

http://www.meetup.com/NYCAsianMeetup/pages/Disclaimer

END

results.description:
*** Multi-group meetup ***


It's time to get kicking. Kick your neighbor. Kick your brother. Kick the big red ball. Just don't kick your dog. Game. On.

If you don't know, now you know ...

If you've never played the game of kickball as a kid you must have grown up on Mars. But as a quick primer, it's a game with rules similar to baseball -- except instead of using a bat to hit a little ball, you use your feet to kick a ball about 10x the size of a baseball. Kick the ball, run to the base, avoid getting your ball caught mid-air or yourself tagged out. Easy. And no athletic skill is necessary, just the ability to kick! Go out and practice now to get ready. Kick the postman when he delivers your bills. Kick that neighbor who won't turn down his stereo. Just get kicking!

If you haven't played the game in 20 years, here are the general rules we will be using https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/64476072/Kickball%20Rules.pdf.</a>

A $3.00 organization fee will be collected at this event, your host is in the running for hardest working person on meetup.

The important stuff ...

• This is a co-ed game so ladies don't be shy to sign up. And it doesn't matter if you have no athletic ability, you just have to be willing to have a little fun.

• Dress for physical activity! You'll be kicking and running so wear your sneaks, shorts and a t-shirt.

• Rain or similar un-favorable weather cancels the meetup. Not!

• Check the meetup site before leaving for last minute updates as well as my mobile phone number.

• Please DO NOT RSVP if you do not seriously plan to attend as space is limited. No flakes allowed! If you RSVP and I notice that you have a number of no shows or have a history of last minute cancellations, you will be removed.

• Sorry, no guests allowed for this one.

results.description: (Note: See Discussions for proposed agenda). What is Self-Love? What is Happiness? And most importantly, how do we get some? One key is authenticity - how well we know our true selves, are able to gently and lovingly accept who we are (without negative judgments, etc.), and our ability to be courageously ourselves both on the inside and out. Some of the background resources for these meetups will come from the science of positive psychology, as well as Martin Seligman's Authentic Happiness, and Mihaly Csikszentmihalyi's Flow. Join us for a fun, light, yet very informative hour on how we can take the first steps to authentically increase our self-love and happiness.

results.description:
This exhibit is free in conjunction with the Museum Mile Festival. 

Revolution of the Eye: Modern Art and the Birth of American Television explores how avant-garde art influenced and shaped the look and content of network television in its formative years, from the late 1940s to the mid-1970s. Highlighting the visual revolution ushered in by American television and modernist art and design of the 1950s and 1960s, Revolution of the Eye features fine art and graphic design, including works by Saul Bass, Alexander Calder, Marcel Duchamp, Allan Kaprow, Roy Lichtenstein, Man Ray, Eero Saarinen, Ben Shahn, and Andy Warhol, as well as ephemera, television memorabilia, and clips from film and television, including Batman, The Ed Sullivan Show, The Ernie Kovacs Show, Rowan and Martin’s Laugh-In, and The Twilight Zone.

results.name: MUSEUM MILE Revolution of the Eye: Modern Art & the Birth of American Television

results.description:
Part of the larger Annual Museum Mile Festival, El Museo will feature outdoor art-making activities, dance, music performances, and a live performance by Legacy Women, the all-women’s traditional musical group rooted in Afro-Dominican and Afro-Puerto Rican traditions. Music by DJ Mosco spinning house, R&B, and Latin underground, and art-making for the entire family.

Our Meetup

We'll meetup in the courtyard in front of El Museo @ 6pm and enjoy the festivities until 7pm or so, then proceed to walk down the Museum Mile on 5th Avenue, visiting other museums along the way, ending up at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on 88th street & 5th Avenue. After we initially meetup as a group at 6pm, everyone is encouraged to enjoy the festival and visit the other museums at their own pace - we will not be visiting the other museums as a group.

Directions to El Museo:

El Museo is located on Fifth Avenue, between 104th & 105th Streets.

By Bus: Take the #1, #2, #3, or #4 bus lines to 104th Street & Madison Avenue (or Fifth Avenue if you are heading downtown).

By Train: Take #6 train to 103rd Street, walk 3 avenues west to Fifth Ave..

As always, please feel free to call or text [masked] if you have any questions, running late, etc...

Thanks!
-Daniel

About El Museo Del Barrio

Founded in 1969, El Museo del Barrio is recognized as New York's leading Latino cultural institution. Primarily featuring Latin American and Caribbean art, El Museo also takes much pride in specializing in works from Puerto Rico and artists in the Puerto Rican community here in New York City. Since moving to it's current permanent location in 1977, El Museo provides artistic cultural diversity as a member of the famed Museum Mile in NYC.

results.description:
Updated March 8th, 2015

This is one of three sites/listserves that promotes weekly games that have been going on for many many years. Stall counts are used on occasion, cleats are optional, boundaries are flexible, and all skill levels are welcome!

There are two ways to stay in touch outside of Meetup.com:

- Follow us on Twitter: http://www.twitter.com/nycultimate
- Like us on Facebook: http://www.facebook.com/nycultimate

SPRING/SUMMER (Mar - Aug)

As the city warms up we play four times a week. Our main location is Riverside Park, with Morningside as a backup.

There are four days that we play:

- Saturdays at 10am, Riverside Park (103rd and West End)
- Sundays at 1pm, Riverside Park (103rd and West End)
- Tuesdays at 6pm, Riverside Park (103rd and West End - Where we can!)
- Thursdays at 6pm, Riverside Park (103rd and West End - Where we can!)

Damien
[masked]

RIVERSIDE DETAILS

The Riverside location is all the way West just off the water between 102nd and 108th Streets. You can only enter the park at 103rd and 108th. The best way to get there is to take the 1 local to 103rd Street. Walk West until you see an entrance that takes you down to the fields through the park. After walking down the steps from the street, you will see a path that goes left and another that goes right. Walk down the left path until you see a stone wall and stairs that go down to the fields. From South to North there will be one small soccer field surrounded by a track (red 'A' on map), another field with two softball fields (closer to 103rd/104th st) and another that is a giant soccer field (closer to 106th st). After walking down the steps, you will see the small Soccer field on your left. Start from this Southern-most field and walk North on the path to find our game. If you see no one, the meeting spot is the South side of the large soccer field. This spot is identified on the map below, a small square with little dots around it. On days when we can't find space at Riverside, we will move the game to Morningside Park (West 110th St and Manhattan Ave).

MORNINGSIDE DETAILS

The Morningside location is at the corner of 110th Street and Manhattan Avenue. The best way to get there is to take the B or C local to 110th Street. You can also take the 1 train to 110th street at Broadway and then walk East. We will play at the South end of the baseball field parallel to 110th street so that we're not in the way of the baseball games. Riverside will be our backup if for some reason we need to change locations.

+++

OTHER SEASONS...

WINTER (Nov - Feb)

During the colder months we generally play two times a week depending on weather. Our main location is Riverside Park with Morningside as a backup.

There are two days that we play:

- Saturdays at 10am, Riverside Park (108th and West End - Big Soccer Field)
- Sundays at 1pm, Riverside Park (108th and West End - Big Soccer Field)
*Tuesdays/Thursdays at 6pm games don't last long due to decreasing sunlight.

FALL (Sep - Oct)

There are four days that we play:

- Saturdays at 10am, Morningside Park (110th and Manhattan Ave)
- Sundays at 4pm, Riverside Park (103rd and West End)
- Tuesdays at 5:30pm, Riverside Park (103rd and West End)
- Thursdays at 5:30pm, Riverside Park (103rd and West End)

results.description:
There are new rules and <a>regulations</a> concerning the Tuesday <a>night</a> games. Please scroll down and read them all before signing up for the event.


There may not be space for you if you don't.


<a>Table</a> Top Role <a>Playing</a> Game Night!


 

This is the official <a>RPG game</a> night of the NY SciFi/Fan Meetup Group.

 

Every Tuesday night we get together to indulge in <a>Table Top RPGs</a>. There are <a>multiple games</a> going on at once, so getting involved in a game is <a>easy</a>.


For those of you unfamiliar with the term, a Table Top RPG (Role <a>Playing</a> Game) is a type of game where the players create characters based on the  story/system available and one person acts as a storyteller. Everyone interacts and works together to <a>create a story</a> and have a few laughs as well.


New Rules for Signing Up:


How to <a>sign up</a>: There will be at leas two <a>games running</a> each week.  You will be able to see who is running, what games are being <a>played</a>, and who is <a>playing</a> below. There will be a total of six spots <a>open</a> in each game, so if a game has filled up you will not be able to join that game. 


When you <a>sign up</a>, leave a comment stating which game you would like to participate in and your name will be added to the roster. If you would like to leave a game or switch over to another game in <a>progress</a>, simply speak to Justin or Cat. They will let you know if there is <a>open</a> space to do so.


If it is your first time <a>attending</a> a game, we have pre-made characters for you to <a>select</a> from. Beginning on your third RPG event, you may choose to make an original character for whatever game you're currently participating in.


Can I run my own game?: If you would like to run your own game, please contact Justin or Cat to reserve a slot.


Need Dice?: Please bring yours if you have some if you need extra I will provide some.

Games Currently Running:

Jutin: Full Steam Ahead 

A new steampunk-inspired RPG by Justin.

Cat: Monster of the Week

A game of investigating and fighting the things that go bump in the night. This campaign is set in a fictional California city a few years after WWII

Current Roster:

Liz

Joseph

Mike

Alden

results.description:
All events are intended for people who identify as women. Men are encouraged to attend only when noted on a specific event. Our Code of Conduct applies to all events run by Women Who Code, Inc.

**MUST SIGN UP HERE TO ATTEND: **

https://wwcnyc1.typeform.com/to/vJTp62

You will NOT be allowed through security if only signed up via Meetup!

6:00 WWC NYC organizers and speakers arrive @Dropbox

6:30 Arrive/Network/Food

6:55 Welcome from Women Who Code NYC

7:00 Welcome from our host, Dropbox

7:15 Tanya Malan

8:00 Jessica McKeller

8:45 Ashley Zelinskie

9:30 Meetup Ends


Tanya Malan, @tanzy


Tanya is a multidisciplinary designer with a passion for creating user-friendly interfaces through in-browser design. Tanya is currently a senior product designer at Reonomy, a commercial real-estate data and analytics start-up. Prior to her role at Reonomy, Tanya worked in New Zealand and London at a number of start-ups where she led the UX and UI design of a range of web and mobile products across a number of industries. Tanya holds a Masters degree in Screen Production from the University of Auckland.

She will be speaking about the pros and cons of in browser design and the importance of knowing how to code for any designer working in the digital space. 


Jessica McKellar, @jessicamckellar


Jessica McKellar is an entrepreneur, software engineer, and open source developer from San Francisco. She is a Director for the Python Software Foundation, PyCon North America's Diversity Outreach Chair, and a maintainer for several open source projects, including OpenHatch and the Twisted event-driven networking engine. For her outreach efforts in the Python community, she was awarded the O'Reilly Open Source Award in 2013.

How the Internet Works

This talk is an introduction to the Internet's structure and protocols through fun experiments and demos.

We'll use tools like wireshark, Scapy, and Twisted to explore:


• What happens under the hood when you type google.com into your browser bar and press enter


• What data you reveal about yourself as you surf the Web


• How coffee shop Internet access works


• How to propose marriage on your local network via ARP cache poisoning


By the end of this talk you'll:


• Understand the core Internet protocols and how design decisions from the early Internet impact us today


• Have exposure to popular networking tools and libraries


• Think sniffing your own wireless traffic is a fun way to spend a Saturday morning


Ashley Zelinskie, @azelinskie

Ashley Zelinskie is an artist based in Brooklyn, N.Y. Her work blurs the lines between art and technology, and spans a variety of media from sculpture to computer programs. After receiving a degree in glass from the Rhode Island School of Design, Ashley began to experiment with the pairing of artistic media and technology. The work she creates now is designed to be appreciated by both human and computer.


She will be talking about her series Reverse Abstraction:

The Reverse Abstraction series begins with a simple premise: that humans and computers perceive the world through different languages, and what is concrete for one is abstract for the other. The objects and shapes so familiar in human art can be neither perceived nor conceived by computers in their original form. Likewise, the codes that are so familiar to a computer are merely scattered symbols to human sensibility. The Reverse Abstraction series attempts to bridge the gap by constructing traditional objects in dual forms: as the classical object and as the hexadecimal and binary codes that represent them. Thus, abstraction becomes material, the meanings for humans and computers are united, and the duality is resolved.

**MUST SIGN UP HERE TO ATTEND:** https://wwcnyc1.typeform.com/to/vJTp62
results.name: Tech Talks @ Dropbox

results.description:
Suave is a lightweight, non-blocking web server. The non-blocking I/O model is efficient and suitable for building fast, scalable network applications. In fact, Suave is written in a completely non-blocking fashion throughout. Suave runs on Linux, OS X and Windows flawlessly. 

In this session, I’ll show you how to build F# web applications and services using Suave, starting from just 10 lines of code in an F# script file and ending with an application deployed and running on Azure and Heroku. The short talk will be followed by a hands on session where you can play with Suave and build & deploy your own web projects! To get the most from this session please bring along a laptop with F# installed. 


Learn more about Suave at http://suave.io/ and about a Suave + Azure combo in a recent blog post by Scott Hansleman.


Tomas is a long-time F# enthusiast, Microsoft MVP and author of a book Real-World Functional Programming (http://manning.com/petricek) which explains functional programming concepts using C# 3.0 and teaching F# alongside. He leads functional programming and F# courses in London, New York and worldwide. He contributed to the development of F# as a contractor at Microsoft Research in Cambridge and helped create data-manipulation library Deedle while working at BlueMountain Capital in New York. Before starting PhD at Cambridge, he studied in Prague and worked as an independent .NET consultant.

results.description:
** Food and drink will be provided **


PART 1: In-Chip Analytics with SiSense

Some say, if Goldilocks were shopping for BI she would choose SiSense because it's just right.

SiSense claims to combine the best of both OLAP and in-memory technology with it's In-Chip Technology. This session is a thorough review of the SiSense product and a look under the hood.

In-Chip Technology is the latest development in database technology.  It combines the flexibility of in-memory based querying with the speed and robustness of OLAP cubes, without the hardware costs and difficult implementation of traditional solutions. Although only recently developed and released, In-Chip is quickly gaining  popularity due to its increased performance and ability to tackle complex and large data sets.

PART 2: BI Implementation Life-cycle Comparison

With a number of BI tools at our disposal, there still does not exist a BI silver bullet. Where some shine, others seem to have completely missed the boat. We will compare 3 BI front-runners to see where each of these players excel throughout the various stages of a typical BI implementation.

We will compare Qlik vs SiSense vs Tableau in these 7 areas: 

• Basic Data Loading

• Advanced Data Transformation

• Basic Dashboards

• Advanced Dashboards

• Data Security

• Collaboration

• Ongoing Development

Does one stand head and shoulders above the rest, or will each of these contenders leave us wanting more?
results.how_to_find_us: Look for us in the Cafe
results.name: In-Chip Analytics with SiSense; BI Implementation Life-cycle Comparison

results.description:
EVENT TYPE: Dining

ADMISSION: You’ll need a referral for admission. Invitation only. 

DESCRIPTION:

Leave it to the Japanese to create a members-only bar that restores our flagging faith in hidden, members-only bars. Bohemian, the Noho sister of a bar in the Nishiazabu district of Tokyo, is tucked into the back of a building that used to belong to Andy Warhol. To reach the front door, you pass through a hallway dubbed “Basquiat Road” (the artist died in his loft at this address). Inside is an apartmentlike, low-ceilinged room containing just 25 plush seats, including a couple of couches and a six-seat yellow pine bar. The white-walled room is Zen simplicity, from the back bar made of tatami mats to a diorama-like mini Zen garden built into one wall to a central skylight that facilitates the art of “tsukimi sake” (moonlight boozin’). Bartenders serve a mix of signature and classic Asian and American cocktails, plying their craft with such precision that each time they present a drink, they shine a spotlight on it. Kiyo Shinoki, formerly the executive chef at Chanto, tells us Bohemian is more of a restaurant in the evening. He serves a mix of American, French, and Japanese small plates (everything from a burger with homemade pickles to short rib sashimi), and then later in the night, until 2am, the space takes on a lounge vibe, with bossa nova, jazz, and Japanese music. As with the Tokyo original that’s hidden behind a house, there isn’t any standing room, just seating at a row of low-to-the-ground two-tops and a couple of couches. In fact, Shinoki says he wants to maintain a maximum 60 percent capacity.

MENU:

• Dinner Menu 1

• Dinner Menu 2

RESTAURANT GALLERY:

• Inside the restaurant

• A hidden room inside the restaurant

FOOD GALLERY:

• Seafood Paella

• Oysters

• Beef Tarter Flatbread

results.description:
Learn How to Get out of the Rat Race! 

Cashflow 101 is a fun way to learn the basic concepts of Real estate Investing. Your objective throughout the night will be to get out of the rat race and into the fast track! In other words you have to find a way to get out of that 9-5 that we all dislike and step into the life you always wanted to live.

How do you get out of the race race you ask?

Your total monthly passive income has to be higher than your total monthly expenses.

Cashflow 101 is an educational tool in board game format which aims to teach the players concepts of investing by having their money work for them in a risk free setting (play money) while simultaneously increasing financial literacy and stressing the imperative nature of accountability.


There are two stages to the game. In the first, "the rat race", the player aims to raise his or her character's passive income level to where it exceeds the character's expenses. The winner is determined in the second stage, "the fast track". To win, a player must get his or her character to buy their "dream" or accumulate an additional $50,000 in monthly cash flow.

In place of “score cards”, there are financial statements. The game requires the players to fill out their own financial statements so that they can see more clearly what is happening with their money. It generally shows how assets generate income and demonstrates that liabilities and 'doodads' are expenses.
results.name: NY/NJ Cash Flow game night

Voice of the Customer is crucial to product success, particularly to uncover differentiated value. Transforming those insights into revenue can be a minefield unless your organization has the process and tools necessary. In this presentation, Pamela Roach, CEO of Breakthrough Marketing Technology, and Michele Romas of Xerox will present the process and tools they used to successfully commercialize a B2B2C product that delivered a 17% increase in Year 1 Revenue.

Speakers

Pam Roach
Pamela Roach is Co-Founder and CEO of Breakthrough Marketing Technology, a business consultancy that uses an assortment of methodologies including market analytics to generate the facts that make a client’s business better. Pam has managed global marketing organizations, multi-million dollar advertising budgets and led the deployment of global communication campaigns as well as successful e-business strategies. She has expertise in global marketing, building brand equity and branding and communication strategies.

Michele Romas
Michele Romas is a Demand Generation Campaign Manager for the Channel Partner Organization at Xerox Corporation. She was previously with one of the world’s leading media agencies where she managed the launch and optimization of Xerox Europe’s Demand Generation media approach. Her experience includes leading a staff of 20 media strategy and media analytics professionals.

Time: 6:30 – 8:30 PM

7:00 - 8:00 Presentation and Discussion

results.description:
Given by Yasuko Kasaki
Tuesdays from 6:30 – 7 pm
Free

Please join us in the sharing of miracles. Here, your mind can come to rest and you can remember true peace. No experience with meditation is required, and everyone is welcome. We ask only that you make it your intention to sit still, quiet in body and mind, and to listen to; receive and follow my instruction to the best of your ability. You will learn to meditate as you practice. Please arrive for Meditation before 6:30 pm as we don't open our door from 6:30 - 7 pm while meditation is in progress. Kindly refrain from ringing our buzzer during this time.

We at CRS are dedicated teachers and students of A Course in Miracles (ACIM) who are waiting to share miracles with you through our ACIM Healing. We ask the Holy Spirit to bring us directly to whatever seed thought is causing your current issues and we share forgiveness and bear witness to the miracles that are happening in your life. Each week I will share with you a different inspirational message from Holy Spirit. This may take the form of creative visualization exercises, or instruction about the nature and purpose of meditation, or about our true nature and relationship to ourselves, to one another, and to the world. In a sense, this is both a meditation practice and a meditation class.

Some students have been coming regularly for a number of years. Others drop in and out as they have time or need. Some come to learn and grow, others more so simply to calm down, to take time out from the frenetic pace of their busy lives. If you are new and feeling uncertain or shaky, do not hesitate to introduce yourself to some of the other students, to ask questions before or after. Try to observe and emulate the stillness and concentration of others around you whom you sense are most grounded. Soon, you, in turn, may provide inspiration and guidance for others.

While the principles are based on ACIM, it does not matter if you are unfamiliar with ACIM or are not prepared to study it outside of this meditation. You can still take from this practice some very practical, effective lessons, tools, and experiences that can enable you to lead a more peaceful, purposeful, fulfilling and loving life.

Namaste,

Yasuko Kasaki,
Founder
CRS (Center for Remembering & Sharing)
123 4th Ave, 2nd FL (between 12th & 13th streets, above Think Coffee)
New York, NY 10003

Beer and Pizza Starting at 6:30; Talk starts at 6:45.

Rent the Runway's business requires special attention to order fulfillment; not only does the warehouse staff need to manage a typical e-commerce pick-pack-ship workflow, but they also need to juggle returns for every order. This involves inspecting, dry cleaning, and repairing thousands of dresses a day. 

 Making this possible is a custom warehouse management system which makes heavy use of Dropwizard and RabbitMQ. We'll focus on how switching to a loosely coupled architecture of services communicating asynchronously has not only improved the stability of RTR's warehouse software but also made some new product features much easier to build. We'll also discuss some of the pitfalls we've encountered and where we still need to improve.


-Aki Yamada

Join us for a book review of the AMORC book Spiritual Laws That Govern Humanity and the Universe by Lonnie C. Edwards, M.D.

The topic for this week's discussion is Chapter 6 The Essence of the Rosicrucian Order's Teachings.

You can find the chapter here:

Kindle

iBook

About the Book

God has created laws by which the universe is governed. Humanity has continued to set these laws into creative motion through thoughts, prayers, motives, intentions, voices, and beliefs. These are the right tools. In this book the student will learn how to use them always for the good.

Human beings are responsible for creating the good, the beautiful, and the true- all of which we desire to experience. But humans are also responsible for creating that which we do not desire to experience. However, being co-creators with God, the quality of our thoughts, beliefs, and intentions will determine and manifest our world. There is work to do, and those who are on the path with knowledge of God’s attributes and God’s laws, and with love and good will in their hearts, will do that work. This is your guide to put these concepts into practice in our troubled world today!

All are Welcome!

results.description:
Punch Winter in the teeth and start your SPRING with Russian Martial Arts!

Do you want to CONQUER THE FEAR of a violent encounter? 


Do you want to INCREASE YOUR STRIKING POWER and expand your combat potential?


Do you want to learn self defense methods that will work ANYTIME, ANYWHERE and build  MENTAL FOCUS and PHYSICAL PREPAREDNESS that will carry over into every aspect of your life? 

Learn all this and much, much more at NJ RMA Self Defense Group, the official Meetup Group of System of Combat NJ.  Start your NEW YEAR with with Russian Martial Arts, your first class is FREE. 

If you are interested in Systema, Reality Based Self Defense,  Martial Arts, Grappling, Street Defense, or Mobility and Body Awareness, this is the Meetup Group for you.  Men and women, seasoned martial artists and raw beginners alike will benefit from our dynamic classes which are tailored to the level and needs of the students. We focus on providing comprehensive instruction, plenty of personal attention and a relaxed atmosphere where you can train at your own pace and intensity. By mastering and employing the principles of biomechanical movement, selective tension, structural alignment, and active relaxation, you will learn to easily double your striking power, hide your strikes and take-downs within unobtrusive movements, frustrate a skilled grappler, diffuse a violent situation, and escape a panicked or excited crowd. 

About Systema

Systema is a combat style based on ancient Slavic fighting methods which were collected and later codified by the Russian Soviet elite special forces.  It is a devastatingly effective and versatile combative program that can easily stand alone, or augment your existing practice.  The overarching focus is on responding to a threat spontaneously with natural, instinctive movement which strengthens and restores the body, clarifies the mind, and provides a framework for healthy, safe, life-long activity.  Individual classes are fast-paced and varied, ranging in subject from striking mechanics, grappling and ground fighting, evasive movement, weapon defense, sparring, and dealing with multiple attackers to women's self defense and street safety. 

Fees 

Enjoy your first class for free and after that, it is $10 per class with discounts available for pre-payment. No contract required!  Classes are held at 7:00pm on Tuesday and Thursday evenings at the YMHA OF UNION on 501 Green Lane, Union, NJ 07083. 

About the instructor 

Jim has over 25 years of martial arts experience in various styles including Brazilian Jiu-jitsu (BJJ), Silat, Boxing, Mixed Martial Arts (MMA) and Karate.  He is certified to teach Systema by Alex Wilkie (Alex Wilkie's Martial Arts Academy).


When you arrive, let the front desk know you are there for the martial arts class and they will direct you. (You do not have to be a Y-member to attend this class).  For general inquiries or more information, message organizers Jimi D or Drew here on the Meetup page.  If you need to reach the instructor, Jim, for any reason, call

results.description:
Speaker for Tuesday June 9, 2015 - Gary Hoffman of 3HTi

Gary Hoffman of 3HTi will be speaking to us on Tuesday night.  He’ll be coming from a Tradeshow where he’s exhibiting at the Jacob Javitz Center in NYC to present the:

The World’s First Carbon Fiber, Kevlar, Fiberglass 3D printer!

Mark One Carbon Fiber 3D Printer by MarkForged

Carbon Fiber is the lightest, strongest material in the world. The incredible strength of carbon fiber comes from the long, continuous strands that carry load down the entire part. This is why space shuttles, rockets, and Formula 1 cars are constructed from continuous strand carbon. And it’s how we print. Don’t settle for plastic with a dash of chopped carbon fill. Longer is stronger.

Now, you can 3D print parts reinforced with Carbon Fiber, Kevlar or Fiberglass right from your desktop. Nylon and ABS plastic are great for testing form and fit. However adding one of the other materials gives you a part that functions stronger than aluminum with no post processing necessary. You can also select pause points in your print to allow embedded components up to 10 micron accuracy.

The Mark One Carbon Fiber 3D Printer by MarkForged uses proprietary “Eiger” software. Very simple to use, Eiger runs in the browser of any computer that runs Google Chrome. Once you get your Mark One printer, you just login to eiger.io and get started. There are no downloads and no hassles.

See http://nationalinventors.com for more info.

results.description:
This event is being hosted by <a>Dave Cervini's New York Social Network </a>and several of their partner Meet Up groups.  The number of RSVP's listed on this Meet Up reflect only a portion of those actually attending. If you have any questions contact the event organizer [masked].

See the Highline in a totally different way as the sun sets and with the spring cutback which exposes a lot of what is covered during the summer.  You will also have a chance to check out the planets and stars through the telescopes of the Amateur Astronomers Association!  Our tours are designed for fun and friendly members of NYSN and our partner social networking groups.  This is not a tour for tourists but for people who live in and around NY or who are new to the area who want to learn more about the city they live in and the amazing things they are surrounded by every day!  The Highline is New York’s most popular attraction! The Highline is an elevated freight train trestle that operated in NYC from the 1930’s to the 1980’s. After years of neglect The Friends of The Highline have saved the structure and transformed it into a beautiful park featuring many of the elements from its’ rich history! Your tour guide will share the history of the highline and the surrounding neighborhoods and show you amazing photo’s from before the trestle was built, while it was in operation and what it looked like while abandoned.

Join us for a fun evening socializing and learning.  Following the tour the group will go out for food and drinks. $15 includes the tour only.

What to Wear: Dress casual/business casual. Wear comfortable shoes

What to Bring: A camera, a bottle of water for the walk and your sense of adventure!

Can I come alone? Yes 98% of those attending will come on their own.

What to Expect: 10-20 fun and friendly people who are looking to make new friends and learn a little about the city.

The group will meet at the bar at The Death Avenue Cafe on 10th and 28th from 6:30-7pm (Come closer to 6:30pm if you wish to have a pre-tour cocktail or nosh) we will end at Gansevoort street. Following the tour the group will likely go out for food and drink. Tour duration approx: 90 minutes.

Please bring exact change if possible: $15

In case of poor weather we will send updates prior to the tour
results.name: NY Tours For New Yorker's Sunset Stargazing Highline History Tour

results.description:
We will be near the piano, come look for us.

 

Let's tame some idioms and some accents !!

This week we're continuing with a combined session: about half our time taming idioms as usual, and the second half working on accent reduction and pronunciation.

All our native tongues introduce elements that we bring to learning English as a Second Language. Let's continue talking and freely discussing these roots of our "accent and pronunciation problems” and see what we can do about them. They can be a source of pride in your heritage and identity, but still you may want to reduce them somewhat to be better understood in English. Let’s take a look together, and find your comfort zone!

In this and future sessions, we’ll listen to individual people's concerns and problems with their own speech, and their difficulty in understanding others talking English. All who like will have an opportunity to speak and be open to the polite, good-natured responses of the group.

Please come if you feel comfortable talking about your own speaking and accent problems and would enjoy the give and take  of the rest of the group about theirs. Tell us what you feel are your biggest concerns, what letters, combinations of sounds, whatever bothers you the most. If you come and decide not to take a turn speaking, that's cool too. There will be other occasions in the future when you may feel bolder to try.

This is a work in progress and we’ll change the format as we see how we do.

Let’s tame some idioms AND some accents!
results.name: Taming Idioms and Accents and Other Wild Animals !!!

group.name: Taming Idioms and Other Wild Animals in NYC

results.description:
Go is an increasingly popular, performant server side language, its designers at Google placed simplicity in the focus. At this hands-on session we'll learn Go together in the Randori format (dojo.wikidot.com/randori). 

Attila Maczak (https://github.com/macat) is going to introduce us the language!  

Pizza and drinks will be provided as usual! :) 

Randori Format

• The presenter explains the coding challenge and starts the Randori with a pair from audience. 


• The pair will use TDD (Test-Driven Development). 

• One half of the pair is changed every 5 minutes

• The pair on the keyboard should continuously explain what they are doing. 

• The pair on the keyboard should stop when someone from the audience falls off the sled — and only continue when that someone is back on track again. 

Agenda

19:00 - 19:15 Introduction to the Coder's Dojo and this session's coding challenge 


19:15 - 20:00 Coding 

20:00 - 20:10 Break 


20:10 - 20:50 Coding 

20:50 - 21:00 Retrospective
results.name: Hands-on session: Learn Go in Randori
