results.description:
First Timers, READ details before you RSVP.  

Where: The Cliffs at LIC, [masked]th Drive, Long Island City, NY


When: We usually climb between 6:00pm and 9:00 pm. There is no strict start time and the organizers tries their best to be there around 6:00pm. We will pair off around 6:15ish and start climbing. 

Transportation: Subway: E, M trains to 23rd St-Ely Ave (1/2 block from gym) 7, G train to Court Square (2 blocks from gym)* N, Q train to Queens Borough Plaza (10min walk) *Walk to the E & M track for those bad weather days 

Metro North & LIRR: From Grand Central take 7 train 3 stops From Penn Station take Uptown E train to Court Square

Cost/Discount: Monthly membership of $105 (the $99 Initiation Fee is waived if you sign up during the meet up). Just mention "Rock & Ice" at the front desk in order to receive your discount. Gear rental is free for first-timers ONLY (first time visit to the facility). Regular gear  pricing info can be found here: http://thecliffsclimbing.com/lic/climbing/pricing/ 
For Beginners, Climbing 101 class is offered 50% Off if you do it the same day as the meet up and has to be scheduled in advance with them.</a><a href="http://thecliffsclimbing.com/lic/climbing/pricing/">

How to meet us:  After you checked-in, to the right of the front desk there's a sitting area.If you see a group of people in there that's probably us come and say hi. If you are running late leave a comment on the website. If you can't find the group just ask at the front desk.  Food/drinks apres-climb if the group decides.

Notice to Beginners: If you have never climbed before, we encourage you to take the Climbing 101 class there before attending the meetup. We get a discounted price of $25 for the class (that's 50% Off original price if you do it the same day as the meet up and has to be scheduled in advance with them). This will also cover your day pass + gear for the day. Unfortunately we can't teach you how to belay or let you try to belay at the gym if you are not belay certified yet. We leave the teaching to the experts.  Check out Cliff's website for more details.  What to wear - comfortable clothes (think yoga).

Notice to newcomers: You need to pass a belay certification. If you had belayed before, the test takes couple of minutes. If you need a refresher, a test partner or belay partner, feel free to see me. Here is the link to The Cliffs LIC http://thecliffsclimbing.com/lic/

If you decide to stick with the sport, please peruse our message boards for good deals on climbing shoes and other gear.  Also if you find this group invaluable, please donate and pay your voluntary membership due ;) the Organizers will love you more ;).
results.name: Midweek Climbing at the Cliffs LIC

results.description:
Network with fellow entrepreneurs and learn from the entrepreneurial journey of Linute, an event planning app that promotes spontaneity and last-minute tendencies.

Pizza and beer will be served. Looking forward to seeing new and familiar faces! 

6:00 — Networking & Refreshments
6:55 — 10-Second Introductions
7:00 — Presentation
7:30 — Questions and General Discussion
8:00 — Networking until 8:30

Linute is an event planning app that promotes spontaneity and last-minute tendencies. It is the brainchild of a couple of kids from Queens, who brought together a handful of different talents and personalities in order to create an efficient, diligent, and only semi-dysfunctional team. 

Linute allows you to host events for your crew, discover new favorite places and interact with new & old friends. You can create events to be published on your and your friends’ Timelines, and control who sees your event by making it invite-only, private, or public. 

Linute does all of the planning work for you. All events on your Timeline and Discover feeds happen within 24 hours, and then disappear. Everything you scroll upon is happening now—without cluttering your inboxes. 

Linute utilizes a clean, simple interface in order to help you find your next move without much effort on your part.

App Store | Facebook | Twitter | Instagram

Nabeel Alamgir was born in Bangladesh, moved to Kuwait when he was 7 and to America 7 years after that. He learned English by watching movies, mostly Scorsese, and worked under the ethic instilled by his parents in order to excel in high school and get into Syracuse University as a pre-med student at 19 years old. This plan was how his father—a cab driver in New York City—wanted him to reach his full potential. Nabeel saw a different path. 

Forfeiting his free ride to be free, Nabeel dropped out after a year and a half, straining the relationship with his father. The word entrepreneur did not exist in the Alamgir household. Golden Boy turned renegade, it was a fight against power—totally foreign to the culture in which Nabeel grew up. There was a complete lack of clarity between the idea of disobedience and that of initiative. 

Nabeel went from working for Apple at 17 years old to bussing at the flagship Bareburger, to finally getting a shot at Corporate. He put in many hours at the Corporate Bareburger building, starting first with only the company’s Ping-Pong table as his workspace, constantly interrupted for the higher-ups’ coffee requests. 

Euripedes was Nabeel's mentor from when he was 17 years old, and continuously came through as a lifesaver. Through a series of promotions over two diligent years he became VP of marketing, a job in which he excels to date. When his best friend mused an idea about a spontaneous event planning app, Nabeel called upon his former Apple Genius experience to help turn that idea into a reality. Valuing the importance of team over technology, Nabeel dipped into many of his social circles and selected a variety of talents and personalities. He singlehandedly brought together the group of misfits who can only be described as a Dream Team.

results.description:
Have you ever wondered...

• How to water specific crops at different stages of life?

• How to install drip irrigation like a boss?

• How to make the most of rainwater harvesting?

• What is the complex relationship between soil and water that enables plants to grow best?

Then apply for Farm School NYC's two-week Irrigation course!

Read more about our instructors, this course, and our School...

or

Apply for Farm School NYC's Irrigation Course now!


With farmers and co-teachers Lorrie Clevenger and Maggie Cheney, you will explore a diversity of techniques and practices, applicable to both larger farm designs and smaller urban plots. You will focus on two major ways of irrigating: drip and rainwater harvesting. Course topics and readings will be put into context through slides, guest speakers - including East New York Farms' agriculture director Deborah Greig and Brooklyn Grange's Head Farmer Ben Flanner, group discussions, and hands-on projects.  

Class Schedule + Locations:  

• Wednesday, June 10th, 6 pm - 9 pm

• Saturday, June 13th, 10 am - 2 pm


• Wednesday, June 18th, 6 pm - 9 pm


• Saturday, June 20, 10 am - 2 pm

Wednesday courses take place in a midtown Manhattan location; Saturday classes will be held in local farms and gardens.


Course Tuition:

The full tuition for this two-week, 14-hour course is $220. As part of our mission to make our courses accessible to everyone, Farm School NYC's tuition is on a sliding scale based on household income. Subsidized tuition is available for those who qualify.  See our application for more information.


Our Instructors:

Lorrie Clevenger, Farmer and Co-Owner, Rise + Root Farm, Millerton, NY

Maggie Cheney, Head Farmer, Sol Flower Farm, Millerton, NY


Read more about our instructors, this course, and Farm School NYC!
results.name: Farm School NYC Irrigation Course

results.description:
Sun Choi studied B.A. in Fine Arts at Hong-Ik University, and Choi's recent artworks show her great interest on social issues and environmental problems. Specifically, she has used pig fat as her painting material to represent 2011 foot-and-mouth disease (FMC) in Korea. Arist Choi also applied and created works of art by using invisible materials such as breath, body heat, wind, smell, and other materials taken from social happenings not only in Korea but also surrounding countries. The artist believes that the artwork's value is no longer in an artist's genius or his/her inviolable aura. She has been creating artworks which find its meaning through the communication and interaction with people.

Born in the south of France, Véronique Gambier started to paint on large scale canvases at the age of 12 under the guidance of French Master Pierre Pallut, developing a strong sense of color and abstraction. She attended L’école des Beaux Arts de Toulon (College of Fine Art of Toulon) and L’école des Beaux Art de Luminy (Luminy College of Fine Art) in Marseille. In the beginning of her career, Gambier chose to pursue a career in fashion, but later changed her career as a Graphic Designer. Finally, she decided to devote her time as a painter, and currently working and living as an artist in New York. Gambier’s creative process is about exploring color, shape and texture for its distinct resonance to an emotion. She seeks to express tension on a canvas rather than harmony, movement rather than stillness.

Daphne Ji Yeon Jang received B.A. in Sculpture from Ga Chon University.Through her video works, Jang is bringing new meaning to classical sculptures. Jang's artworks show sculptures as moving images in 3D computer space. She uses the classical sculptures that can be found in the museums and adds movement to form a moving sculpture with a new story and contemporary background or materials. Namely, she is giving lives to the sculptures which were once motionless and bringing them to the modern time. Through her moving sculpture video installations, Artist Jang hopes to share feeling of courage, trust, sacrifice, love, and compassion.

Artist Dong Jin Jeon, who studied M.F.A. and B.F.A. in Fine Arts from Keimyoung University, uses 'draw' and 'repeat' for his main motifs in his artworks. Artist Jeon repeatly draw thin lines on a large canvas and creates a monochrome image. According to the artist, the repetitive drawing methiod is not accidental but intentional. He believes the painful repetitive actions are like a life of human that after he completed the work and overcame the movement of self-torture, it brings such a great catharsis. Artist Jeon stated: "As a human devotes his or her life for the death, my work is also some repetition of permanent, unveiled procedure toward unknown ending."

Andy H. Jung, who received M.F.A. in Photography from Pratt Institute in New York, illustrates desires of human in his photography. According to the artist, humans are animals of desire. Human's desire toward new and artificial things became the objects of our desire in the world, and even after they possess what they desired, they constantly looking for new objects. Jung's works of art try to connect tangible and man-made objects with his ethereal memories. Through his photography, the artist hope to communicate with both artificial object and the collective memories in a singular and unified image. Namely, he wishes to evoke a visceral connection between external world of humans and the internal world of human minds.

Minso Kim received M.F.A.in Art & Technology Studies from School of the Art Institute of Chicago, and her works of art depict the physical imprints of diverse human connectivity. According to the artist, her artwork is functioning at the center of poetics, translation, and technologies, and delivering crude feeling of text through manifesting the sounds of human language. Artist Kim has great interest on the limitation of language. She believes that although humans use language to deliver their feeling, sensation, and thoughts to one other, it is difficult to perfectly understand one's messages in language. Through the artwork. such as her recent works of art. Lost in Translation and A Letter to You, Kim is trying to represent the interaction between feeling and fact, subjective and objective views via languages.

The opening reception and preview event will be open to public on Wednesday, June 10th from 6:00 P.M. to 8:00 P.M.

results.description:
If you've been wondering how to add some humor to your presentations, whether formal or informal, come to a meeting of Humorous Toastmasters.  This is a "specialty" club - open to anyone interested in joining, but which specializes in encouraging experimentation with humor in every aspect of the meeting, from introductions to prepared speeches.  As our club president used to say, we're not funny people, we're people trying to become funnier.

The 2nd Wednesday each month we meet here at Jimmy's - a lovely bar where we have a backroom with mini stage, cafe tables, and a lower east side atmosphere.  The 4th Wednesday of each month we meet in a corporate environment midtown (watch for those announcements too!)

For more information about the international Toastmasters program, go to www.Toastmasters.org
results.how_to_find_us: This is between 7th and 8th Avenues - club meets in the room down the stairs in the back of the bar.
results.name: Come to Humorous Toastmasters!

This event is being sponsored by Dave Cervini's New York Social Network and several of their partner Meet Up Groups.  The number of RSVP's listed on this Meet Up reflect only a portion of those actually attending

This may be the friendliest and most social After Work Happy Hour you will every experience! Forget about crowded rooftops, long lines to get in and people with attitudes.  New York Social Network founder Dave Cervini personally welcomes members of NYSN and several Social Networking Meet Up Groups to The  Playwright in the heart of midtown to socialize, network and connect in a fun and friendly atmosphere. 

Stop in for a drink or stay a bit longer, you'll be sure to meet other fun and interesting people.  Come alone or bring a friend, either way you will be glad you did. This is a great event for new members to come out and find out what our group is all about plus mix and mingle with long time members and their friends.

The night will feature...

-Drink specials

-Fun ice breakers games with prizes

-NYSN staff on hand to welcome you and introduce you to others at the event. -Music played at conversational levels

-FREE admission  

Can I come alone? Yes, 95% of those attending come on their own. Our staff will be on hand to welcome you and introduce you to others in the group.

What to expect:[masked] people ages 20's - 40's

What to wear: Business casual/stylish

Why should I come?  To make new friends, meet people from other groups, learn about NYSN programs and events, find out about other things going on with similar groups, network for business, make a personal connection, check out a new place or just get out of the apartment

Do I need to RSVP? No, but it does help us to see how many to expect and send any special messages that may need to go out.

If you have any questions before you register please e-mail [masked] or call[masked]-2256.  We want to make sure that this party is exactly what you are looking for so that you'll come out again and again!

results.description:
Tech Town is back in a big way for Summer 2015! It's been a while since we've all seen each other, and so much has happened in NYC tech and marketing since then!

We'll be kicking it off with our first 'Networking Over Drinks' of the year, happening on Wednesday June 10th, 6-8pm at WeWork Park South.


Since we last met, we've got some awesome new members to welcome and tons of returning members with exciting new hustles to catch up with, so let's connect over drinks and explore where marketing and tech are headed this summer!

• Meet others who came here to hustle

• Learn about the local startup & innovation community

• Connect with people who have a passion for marketing & tech

As part of the conversation, we'll talk about the direction of this Meetup group, as well as the potential continuation of the Tech Town newsletter that kept y'all informed of news and events for acclimating to the Innovation Community.

We've also got a new co-organizer joining us this year - Marlayna Augusto is a native New Yorker in the civic tech space, and she's pumped to be helping build this piece of the NYC Startup Community!

Post to this event page with any questions, or email Josh at jcness [at] gmail [dot] com or Marlayna at marlaynaaugusto [at] gmail [dot] com.

And a big thanks to WeWork for hosting us. You're going to love their space!

WeWork is the platform for creators.  They provide the workspace, community, and services you need to make a life, not just a living.  To learn more about the WeWork locations in New York City, send an email to joinus [at] wework [dot] com to book a tour. Make sure to let them know you were referred by Tech Town NYC!
results.name: Tech Town NYC | Networking + Drinks

results.description:
6:00- Pre-Intermediate Level

Intermediate WCS is a continuation for students who have completed the Beginner Level or possess a good understanding of the basic patterns as well as,  the principles of timing and partnering. Emphasis will be on the continuing development of partnering skills, lead and follow, dance floor etiquette, a good understanding of timing, and the ability to execute simple sequences. New steps and turn patterns will be introduced and linked together to develop new combinations.


7:00-Intermediate Level

8:00- Beginner Level

Beginner WCS Level is an introductory course, which gives a foundation of movement for students who have had little or no dance experience. Emphasis will be on the development of partnering skills, lead and follow, the basic principles of timing, as well as basic foot work and basic patterns.

We suggest between 2 and 4 months in Beginner Level  before you move on to the next Level.

9:15- WCS Party

Can I come alone? Yes, 95% of those attending come on their own. Our staff will be on hand to welcome you and introduce you to others in the group.

What to expect:[masked] people ages 20's - 40's

What to wear: Business casual/stylish

How do I get there? It is across the street from Penn  Station.

Why should I come?  To make new friends, meet people from other groups, learn about NYSN programs and events, find out about other things going on with similar groups, network for business, make a personal connection, check out a new place or just get out of the apartment

Do I need to RSVP? No, but it does help us to see how many to expect and send any special messages that may need to go out.

If you have any questions before you register please e-mail [masked] or call[masked]-2256.  We want to make sure that this party is exactly what you are looking for so that you'll come out again and again!

Latam Tech

The goal of the Latin America Tech Meetup is to bring members of tech community, including noted entrepreneurs and investors, to discuss trends and opportunities in the convergence of startups, technology and Latin America.

Our Special Guest


Scott Heiferman is Co-Founder and CEO of Meetup, the world's largest network of local community groups. Over 50,000 Meetups (self-organized community events) happen each week. Millions of people in over more than 100 countries using Meetup. Scott graduated from The University of Iowa. He is an angel investor in Betaworks, Founders Collective, Virgance, 20x200. Scott was named an MIT Technology Review "Innovator of the Year".

6:00 Drinks & Food

6:30 Fireside chat with Scott Heiferman (Co-Founder & CEO of Meetup)

7:30 Networking


Hosts


Adrian Avendano, founder of the Latin America Tech Meetup in NYC and SF and CEO of Peoplehunt. Adrian was born in Mexico City, raised in New York City, and has lived in Chile, Ireland, Germany, Netherlands, Denmark, UK, and San Francisco. His obsession is making things that change the world. He started his fist company in Ireland in 2008. Since then he has been startingtech companies that connect people face to face. Yahoo bio press http://yhoo.it/1kx3yqc

Felipe Saenz, was born in Colombia and grew up in Miami; is the Founder & CEO of uchi8 and co-organizer of the LatAm Tech Meetup. Uchi8 is a platform that digitizes the middle man for musicians and later on for any type of digital content creator. Some backers uncluding a University part of Berklee's College of Music. Felipe has also gathered his team of five, to make uchi8 a reality.

results.name: Suggested Event: Fireside Chat: Scott Heiferman (CEO and co-founder of Meetup)

results.description:
***CLOSING REGISTRATIONS COB TODAY***

On Wednesday June 10th @ 6 PM, you will have the opportunity to discover 8 start ups this time, at Atelier, the co-working space launched and housed by Belcham, the Belgian-American Chamber of Commerce in NYC. This very special edition will feature 4 Belgian and 4 Dutch/Netherlands companies, in parallel with the Northside Festival in Brooklyn. 


| Please note these changes! |

1) Each company will have 5 minutes to present followed by 3 minutes Q&A

2) A nominal charge of $10.00 will be requested when you register. (As we're at capacity, this will enable us to scale-up in terms of attendee quality, as well as cover part of our costs for staging and organizing the event - reminding you that we are a non-profit)

I'm happy to announce the new names of our participating startups:

*** From Belgium, with love:

- HSTRY

Hstry is a digital learning tool that enables teachers, students and historians to create and explore interactive timelines. Using a platform designed to mimic social media, Hstry presents content in a format that is easily understood, engaging, and familiar to the 21st century student. With Hstry, teachers facilitate discovery as students explore primary sources, create timelines, and engage with history.


- Broke Bikes

It was the summer of 2012 when the idea of building a bicycle brand first popped in our heads. Driven by a dream to bring back fun and colour into the world of cycling, we started on a 2-year long quest to build the perfect bike and make this dream a reality. You see, we believe it’s our mission to build stunningly beautiful bikes that are equal parts fun to ride and easy to maintain. Built using only high quality components but without an eye-watering price tag.

- MediaHaven

MediaHaven is the SaaS media asset management platform for any organization that wants to professionally manage and distribute its audio-visual material for marketing, training, and external and internal communication. The user interface is designed to support novice as well as expert users in managing their media content.


- NewsAnglr

If you are an investor reading an article that brings up new elements to a business you invested in, you might want to find out more. You don't want more of the same, but additional information. Here often starts an explorational journey on the web. We can make this much easier. With 1 click NewsAnglr retrieves similar content out of millions of articles and analyses the related content for informational clusters offering users an overview of the major topics. Any professional who is interested in content that offers real value can benefit.

*** From The Netherlands, with love:

- iLost

iLost has the ambition to become the Google of Lost & found. No more filling out forms or making phone calls when you've lost your keys, phone or wallet. Simply check online where your lost property is found and have it delivered back home the next day.

- Leviy

We are a young team of highly motivated professionals ready to change the daily world of facility management. The name LEVIY means “bringing people together” and that is our key goal. By developing tailor made and unique software applications we make daily processes

- MADS

MADS.com real-time supply-side RTB platform helps publishers to generate and maximise revenues from their (mobile) applications and sites by delivering the most relevant advertising to their audiences via automated trading (RTB). MADS.com means: More Revenue! Full Control! No Hassle!

- Looklive

LookLive makes the apparel, shoes and accessories in celebrity images and TV shows interactive and shoppable. This is valuable because LookLive unlocks the fashion and commerce potential of TV shows and celebrity images turning them into a new, large opportunity to drive sales, create revenue, new advertising opportunities and valuable connections between TV shows, celebrities, retailers, brands and shoppers. LookLive does this through building scalable, proprietary machine learning (artificial intelligence) technology that supports identifying the actual products that appear on the celebrities, TV show characters and music videos. The same technology also creates “style profiles” for users that predict products and trends they will be most interested in .

I look forward to see you all again in big numbers for what is going to be another one of this memorable moments !


As always, beer for our MeetUps is sponsored by Duvel.

Be there or be square - and share the word.

Yvan De Munck

Register here: http://www.reianyc.org/61015-how-to-find-an-apartment-deal.html

Your Investment:

Members: $15 / Door $20 

Guests:  $30 / Door $40

Note: We encourage you to register online early as 1) door registration is more and 2) seating is on a first come, first serve basis and not guaranteed. 

You may have heard that this is the “Year of the Apartment Building”. The apartment market is booming, and it’s not too late to get active in this exciting real estate strategy. Often real estate investors ask me “How do I find an apartment deal?”

Join my friend and colleague Chris Urso of Elite Apartment Coaching, who will break down the HOWof finding an apartment deal. He’ll cover:

The State of the Apartment Market for the rest of 2015 Deal Sourcing Strategies How you can get started investing in apartments this year!

Speaker: Chris Urso, Founder of Elite Apartment Coaching 

Christopher Urso is an investor, author and private real estate coach. His real estate investment company, URS Capital Partners, currently controls over $55,000,000 worth of apartments throughout the Midwest and Southeast and has raised over $18 million is private money. He has been featured as a Master Real Estate Investor by Personal RE Investor Magazine. 

In 2011, alongside his wife Lisa, Chris created his coaching program Elite Apartment Coaching with a mission to help private real estate investors play a bigger game and create true wealth with the power of apartments. 

In the last three years his coaching program has helped his clients purchase over $44,000,000 worth of real estate in 10 states. Through the Elite Apartment Coaching Program, Chris is able to truly change the lives of his clients, and guide them to their financial goals.

Register here: http://www.reianyc.org/61015-how-to-find-an-apartment-deal.html

results.description:
Who: Joel and Moshe will be the hosts of the meetup. Please find them if you need belay partners.


Where: Brooklyn Boulders 575 Degraw St, Brooklyn, NY 11217

When: We usually climb between 6pm and 9pm. There is no strict start time and the organizers try their best to be there around 5pm. If you are new, please feel free to warm up on an easy bouldering wall and find us later if you need a belay partner.

Transportation: By subway: Take the 2, 3, 4, 5, N, Q, R, B, or D to Atlantic-Pacific, transfer to the R for one stop to Union St. Walk 2 blocks north, turn left on Degraw, we are the last door on the right side of the street.

Cost/Discount: get a meetup discount if you sign up with our group which gives you $19 entrance + FREE gear rentals. You can bring your friends and they will get the same discount from us. Just mention "Rock & Ice" at the front desk in order to receive your discount and free rentals.

How to meet us: If you need a belay partner, come find the organizer(s). Come say hi even if you don't need a partner. Sometimes we grab drinks/food apres-climb.

Notice to beginners: if you have never ever climbed or belayed before you will need to take a class - it takes place every night at 7pm. There is a nominal fee for this. What to wear - comfortable clothes (think yoga).

Notice to newcomers: You need to pass a belay certification. If you had belayed before, the test takes couple of minutes. If you need a refresher, a test partner or belay partner, please see feel free to see me. I usually get to the gym around 6pm, and either boulder at the entrance wall or top-rope in the main room. I post a comment what I'm wearing that day the afternoon of.

Here is the link to BKB: </a><a target="_blank"><a target="_blank"></a><a target="_blank">http://www.brooklynboulders.com</a>;;

If you decide to stick with the sport, please peruse our message boards for good deals on climbing shoes and other gear.
results.how_to_find_us: hi, just ask at the front desk for location of rock & ice meetup group when checking in :)

The parking lot is located on the south side of Rte 117 approximately halfway between Route 9A to the East and Route 9 to the West. There are gates and stone walls at the entrance, a little toll booth, a visitors' center, & bathrooms.

This meetup group was started by the founder of the DaniWeb.com IT Discussion Community who was getting frustrated that all of the meetups she was interested in attending were based in NYC, and it was nearly impossible to get to them on weeknights for people who work out on Long Island.

Join a group of people who work in the tech industry throughout Long Island.

We are a very informal group consisting mostly of web developers and IT consultants, with the occasional application developer thrown into the mix. We talk about the latest projects we're working on and get help and feedback from each other.

The meetup starts at 6 pm but running as late as 10 or 11 pm (sometimes even later!) is the norm. People typically arrive anytime between 6 pm and 9 pm, so don't miss out just because you can't get there by 6. There's usually an early crowd and a late crowd.

results.description:
Every Wednesday in June we'll be bringing some serious board game madness to Berg'n from 6:00 PM to 11:00 PM. They like board games; we like board games... it's a match made in heaven!

We'll be bringing our usual pile of fun games and in addition Brooklyn Brainery will be loaning us some! So we will have multiple copies of classics like Settlers of Catan, Ticket to Ride and Carcasssonne on hand. As always though there will be lighter party games and longer more in depth games as well. Whatever your poison we'll hook you up.

Check out brooklynbrainery.com to learn about the tons of cool classes and events they put on!

Also thanks to Berg'n for letting us use their awesome space! For the month of June we will be alternating between the private space (June 3rd and 17th) and their common space (June 10th and 24th). When you come in though all you to do is look for a pile of games to know where we are. The entrance to the  private space is located right past the coffee bar setup.

Just a quick reminder not bring in outside food and to patronize any bar that hosts us. Check out bergn.com if you want to check out their food and drink menu; they have a great selection.

HOW MUCH IS THIS EVENT?

There's no admission fee, but there is a two drink minimum* which you will be expected to honor.

* (or monetary equivalent in non-alcoholic purchases if you don't touch the stuff.) 

WHAT TYPE OF GAMES ARE PLAYED?

All types. Real short bluffing games decorated with skulls and flowers. Cooperative games fighting horrible diseases. Classic euro games where you haggle over sheep and wheat. Whether you want to fight unspeakable horrors in Arkham or build railroads across America or rebuild your farm after the black plague (more fun than it sounds) you can probably find a game you would like.

Some games you might see are 7 Wonders, Settlers of Catan, Pandemic, Dominion, Dixit, Puerto Rico, Eldritch Horror, Ticket to Ride, Carcasonne among many others. You're also welcome to bring any game you want to play!

 I DON'T KNOW THESE GAMES? IS IT COOL IF I COME?

We're very friendly and if you have no idea what the hell we're talking about just trust us when we say it's ton of fun. We'll have tons of games and we're very happy to show you the rules. Hang out, haves some drinks, and learn a new game.

Questions? Comments? Contact us at [masked]
results.how_to_find_us: We'll be either in the private room or the main room. Either way look for the people playing games!

results.description:
The next open mic will be outdoors at a new community space in my neighborhood.  Lower Broadway Neighborhood Association has been working to transform a vacant lot into a welcoming space.  And we would like to support these efforts.  We also thought it would be nice to introduce people to the space and see it's possibilities when a group of creatives come together.

We are still figuring out where BeCOMe's new home will be.  We didn't really pick Coffee Cave.  There was just this feeling like, "This is it.  Let's do this."  I guess that is the feeling we are waiting for.  But this community space is about as close to home as it gets.  Hope you will join us in celebrating this new space for our neighborhood.

-Hala

BeCOMe aka Brick City Open Mic is a space for people to "become" who/what they want to be.  It is a lifelong process and so we are reaching out to all creative types to join us.  The goal is to truly be an "open" mic welcome to all kinds of talents, artists, and entertainers, of all skill levels.

This is also an open jam, an open floor, and an open forum.  Please, bring your instruments, your thoughts, your feelings, your jokes, and your friends.

We have PA and our band, Lot on 7th, is the house band.  So far, I think we have done a good job in creating a welcoming and supportive atmosphere.  Hope to see you next month!
results.name: BeCOMe (this is happening)

Valley Stream train station is very close about three blocks.

For those who drive:

• Street parking meters are until 6pm. If you come early, W. Jamaica Ave has a free parking lot, behind the pizzeria.


We have permission from the restaurant owner to play in the restaurant on the condition that everyone consumes something. At least a soda. The restaurant also has a bakery attached with treats.

We play in the restaurant; to get there, you enter the bakery walk to the back, then make a right. There you'll find the restaurant, we are located by the front windows.

• The bakery is located across the street from Mitchell's restaurant. There is a lighted OPEN sign on the window.

**Due to popular demand we will now be having a 3 no show rule. If you RSVP but can't make it please take the time to take yourself off. results.description:
Weather: Check back for any cancellations due to poor weather or otherwise.

Transit: 2 or 5 trains to E 174th St stop and short walk. 5 train runs express until 7PM from E 149th St-Third Ave to E 180th St. BX17, BX21 and BX11 within walking distance

• Court number/location will be announced in comments upon arrival.

Ready? Play.
_____________________________________________________

What will we be doing at the Meetup?
We will be meeting at the tennis courts for some friendly rallying, doubles, and singles play*. This meetup is open to players at any skill level; from beginner to advanced.

*For those of you who are interested in singles play, please keep in mind that the ability to play singles predicates on the amount of members who have RSVPed as well as court availability at the meetup event's venue. We cannot guarantee singles play in every instance.

How long will the meetup be?
The time listed for the meetup event is when you can expect to the event host to be there. If you would like to arrive earlier or later than the start time listed, please leave a comment in the meetup event you plan to attend. This will give everyone in attendance a good representation of who is showing up at what time.

What will it be like?
Our group is very friendly and loosely organized to allow for a fun experience.

Upon arrival, our event host will announce which court they are on in the comments of the meetup event. If you have a smartphone, we strongly suggest that you download the Meetup app for iPhone or Android to make communication easier.

When you arrive at the courts, look for the event host listed or other members of the group playing on (or near) the courts listed. Use the photos of each host/member on the website as a frame of reference.

Introduce yourself. Let the host know your level of play and you will be assigned to a court immediately.

Do members need to bring anything?
All members must bring their own racquet. Unfortunately, we do not supply racquets.

All members are encouraged to bring a fresh can of new balls. You can always use a marker to mark your initials on your ball if you would like to keep them for future play. Please keep in mind that tennis balls only last a couple of days after taking them out of the can before they lose their bounce.

If you plan to donate to the group, you can leave your donation with the meetup event host or the head organizer, Frank, if he’s in attendance. All donations go towards the fees required to organize the meetup.

Who should come? Are newcomers welcome?
Our meetup event is open to all players whether they're an absolute beginner or an advanced player. Players will be matched up with others based on their skill level. Beginners will be given an opportunity to play with higher level players so they can gain more experience with higher consistency.

It is a high priority for our group to help beginners increase their skill and become better players. If you are reading this and are an absolute beginner, please don't be intimidated. We want you to join us and have fun.

What should a newcomer expect?
If you're new to the group, you'll learn very quickly that our community is extremely friendly. We have a colorful cast of characters from all walks of life who are ready and willing to have a good time.

Whether you're interested in easy-going rallying or competitive play, we can accommodate you.

Questions?
If you have any other questions, concerns, or comments; please send them to our head organizer, Frank Tirado via email.

results.description:
Git Is Great.

Version control has been around for over forty years - so what makes gitdifferent?  The average git user has a few memorized commands that they use, and fear and trembling beyond that - can't we do better?


In this 25(*) minute talk, Tom Ritchford explains the conceptual roots of git, and why it's a game changer that's applicable to a wide range of projects beyond the software development world.


At the end of this talk, you might not remember a single specific git command, but you will understand what's going on and what questions to ask.

About the speaker.
Tom Ritchford has been writing computer programs since the 1970s.  Currently employed as a senior software engineer at Ripple Labs, he has worked for companies from Google to Drexel Burnham Lambert.  In his spare time, he writes programs for lasers and other lights, which he uses as part of a music show under the name Tom Swirly.

Tomas Laurenzo

Tomás Laurenzo is an artist and academic who works with both physical and digital media to explore the artistic construction of meaning and its relation with power and politics.

In this talk, he will be presenting some of his works, which span across different practices, including installation, interactive art, music, live cinema, and digital lutherie.

http://laurenzo.net/

WHAT WE DO

Open space for artists & technologists to get hands-on with new technology. We supply a bunch of hardware and a chill environment so you can hack away.

Tweet: @hardwarehacklab at #ThoughtWorksNYC

Visit: hardwarehacklab.io

 

 

 

We use creative coding environments like openFrameworks or Max/MSP to play with everything from webcams to Oculus Rift. People of all experience levels, from beginners to veterans are welcome here.

WARNING

 

This meetup has no particular structure. We don't have 'hack lab' projects. We work on whatever we, and you, bring in each week - which could be anything.

 

The schedule is loose, the feeling is social and non-judgemental. We are just curious and want to see your projects. So bring what you have and share!

ROSTER

 

Oculus, Kinect 1/2, Arduino, Leap, Glass, Depth video, Brain-Computer Interface, openFrameworks, SuperCollider, Max/MSP, vvvv, Processing.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

DO YOU HAVE SPECIFIC NEEDS?

Some of these items are only available on request or particular occasions. Use the comments below and direct messages to find out if particular hardware or people with particular skills will be around that week.

 

If you can't confirm, still drop by and meet us. The lab is a great place to come and learn and meet people.
results.name: Hardware Hack Lab - Talk On Git By Tom Ritchford and Art by Tomas Laurenzo

results.description:
Earlier this year, the Knickerbocker Hotel re-opened in its original space at 42nd and Broadway. This classic Old New York venue, which once had its own secret door (which is still there!) in the 42nd Street subway station, had been shuttered since 1920. But the 1906 beaux arts building remained, serving as offices or fashion showrooms before being re-imagined and re-opened as a luxury hotel 95 years after its previous incarnation closed.

The Knickerbocker Hotel bar was where the martini was invented. That in and of itself would be enough reason to pay the Knickerbocker a special visit. But June 10 is also a historic day for the hotel. For it was on this day in 1919 that Amory Blaine, the protagonist in F. Scott Fitzgerald's debut novel, "This Side of Paradise," famously drank away his sorrows in the Knickerbocker Hotel bar under the watchful eyes of Maxfield Parrish's Old King Cole, after Amory's girlfriend Rosalind Connage ended their budding relationship. The same Old King Cole mural now watches over patrons at the St. Regis Hotel bar farther uptown.


It was a pivotal scene in the book and one of the most famous drinking binges in American literature. The scene was modeled after Fitzgerald's own life as his then-girlfriend Zelda Sayre had broken up with him in the summer of 1919 for the same reason that Rosalind dumped Amory: he wasn't successful enough and she didn't think he could offer her a financially secure, comfortable future. Fitzgerald, like Amory a recent graduate of Princeton, drank away the rest of the summer in New York, then returned to his hometown of St. Paul, Minnesota to write his debut novel. Scribner's bought the manuscript and published "This Side of Paradise" to much critical acclaim the following spring. The suddenly more successful Fitzgerald was able to resume his courtship with Zelda and they were married at St. Patrick's Cathedral in New York on April 3, 1920, just a week after "This Side of Paradise" hit bookstores. As for Amory Blaine, you'll have to read the book to find out what happened to him.


So if Dublin can have Bloomsday (June 16) in honor of the Leopold Bloom character in Joyce's Ulysses, New York can honor Amory Blaine and F. Scott Fitzgerald on June 10, especially now that the site of one of the book's most iconic scenes has reopened.

We'll have a reserved space at Charlie Palmer at the Knick on the 4th floor at the Knickerbocker Hotel. In the interest of full disclosure, this is not the original location of the Knickerbocker bar. As you can imagine, much has changed in a venue that just re-opened after 95 years. But it's still the same historic building, with an extensive cocktail menu and the bartenders can make the two drinks featured in the famous scene: the rye highball, which Amory drank, and the Bronx. We'll meet starting at 6:30 and plan a special toast to the unfortunate Amory Blaine at 8:20, the precise time his relationship with Rosalind ended.


So come join us for this unique tribute to Old New York and one of America's greatest novelists. BTW, we are planning an F. Scott Fitzgerald's New York bar tour in September (in honor of Fitzgerald's 119th birthday) so stay tuned.
results.name: Blaine's Day at the Knickerbocker Hotel Bar

Visit us at Metis in New York City on Wednesday, June 10 at 6:30pm to see a Data Visualization with D3.js presentation by Kevin Quealy, Graphics Editor for The New York Times.


Enjoy pizza and drinks as Kevin illustrates how The New York Times uses D3.js for The Upshot, and shares what students learn throughout his upcoming 6-week, evening Data Visualization with D3.js course.

Network with other data visualization enthusiasts and professionals, learn how The New York Times approaches data visualization projects and collaborates with editorial teams, and gain insight into the student experience for the Metis Data Visualization with D3.js course.

6:30 - 7:00 Register, Mingle, Eat & Drink
7:00 - 7:30 Instructor Kevin Quealy presents 
7:30 - 8:00 Chat with Kevin, attendees, Metis staff and enjoy more food & drink 

Kevin Quealy 
Metis Data Visualization Instructor
Graphics Editor, The New York Times
@kevinQ

Kevin Quealy is a graphics editor at The New York Times and a contributor to The Upshot, the Times' data-centric vertical about policy, politics and everyday life. He has taught journalism and data visualization courses at N.Y.U., the University of California-Berkeley and the City University of New York.

Before coming to The New York Times, Kevin served as a Peace Corps volunteer in South Africa. He has a Master's degree from the Missouri School of Journalism and a B.A. in physics from Gustavus Adolphus College in St. Peter, Minnesota.

Connect with us before the event! @thisismetis

results.description:
The Beginner Buddhist Book Circle is for anyone interested in or new to Buddhism. In this biweekly series, we’ll explore classic introductory Buddhist books. Although we have “reading assignments”, the meetings focus more on basic Buddhist teachings rather than strict discussions of the books. Our meetings are casual and informal; all levels of interest and experience are welcome. When possible, we’ll have copies of the current book available at no cost.

*** Right Now We’re Reading: “The Dhammapada” translated by Gil Fronsdal***

The Dhammpada (Teachings of the Dharma) is one of the most popular, widely read, and most accessible of all Buddhist texts. The clear and direct teachings on key topics like meditation, mindfulness, ethics, and compassion are especially well-suited for anyone exploring basic Buddhist teachings.

While there are many translations of the Dhammapada, we’ve chosen to read the version by Gil Fronsdal, frequently cited as the best English version to date. The book is readily available in bookstores and libraries. Furthermore, there are audio versions of all chapters freely available from the Insight Meditation Center.

For the June 10th, 2015 meeting, please read Chapters 10 through 12 (~9 pages).

Discussion points include:

-What does Buddhism say about ethics/morality?


-What are the Five Mindfulness Trainings (Precepts)?


-What is impermanence?

***

Happy reading and we hope to see you soon!
results.name: Beginner Buddhist Book Circle

Club Dance Class

guys & girls are welcome!

Would you like to feel confident on the dance floor?

These classes will prepare you for dancing in public!

How it works:

I, unlike other teachers, don't spend entire class on teaching you choreography - you don't need it unless you want to be a professional dancer. My focus is on teaching you how to move comfortably in a club, at a party, wedding, etc. (Unless of course you request choreography).

I teach basics: finding and keeping rhythm, easy steps you can use anytime making sure you know how to transition smoothly between them.

During the first class I assess what it is we need to work on; whether it's musicality, rhythm, coordination, attenuation, groove etc. From that point on, I adjust the class to students' needs.

You want SaaS? We’ll give you SaaS…

In Partnership with;

Applications open May 11 - July 13 (finalists will be announced August 7th, there will be finalists competition in New York in Sept)

Why apply?

All Finalists

-Finalists will spend the day before the competition meeting with BBVA decision makers (including but not limited to team members from Innovation, Ventures, Digital M&A, Internal Venturing and Business Development)

-Finalists will pitch to a crowd comprised of venture capitalists, angel investors, local entrepreneurs, traditional finance/banking professionals, and last but not least, executives from BBVA

year

results.description:
For our first meetup, 6 people will teach us something awesome about the command line (specifics to follow). If you have an idea and you'd like to present, let us know here. 

Agenda

• 6:30pm - 6:45pm: meet and greet

• 6:45pm - 7:45pm: presentations

• 7:45pm - 8:15pm: meet and greet


• 8:15pm: drinks nearby (TBD)


Presentations

• Intro to Screen - Sha-Mayn Teh 


• Analyzing and reusing your command history - Nathan Hurst

• Creating a homebrew installable project from a Github repo - Tommy Murphy

• Bash scripting case study - Courteney Ervin


• bash_profile - Eric Tang

• Power unix commands - Scott Carleton

Who should come?

The meetup is open to any engineer who is still learning (to us, that means every engineer). We ask that the speakers target their talks for the following background...

If I'm teaching at this meetup, what should I do?

Talks are 10 minutes total including questions. This usually means preparing 5 minutes of content and taking 5 minutes of questions.

To help teachers hone their clarity, we encourage the audience to ask questions during the talks. For now, we’re limiting questions to one question per audience member to keep things moving.

A few other guidelines:

• Make sure you target the topic of the meetup

• Your talk should target teaching engineers something that they can use soon - likely immediately. That means most talks should avoid non-free or and non-open-source software.


• Your talk should be broadly applicable. This means you should avoid avoid company pitches.


• Please practice your presentation all the way through at least once!

Who should I target my talk toward?

We generally expect engineers at all experience levels to be at the meetup, but feel free to make the following assumptions:

• Members have used a scripting language (ex: Ruby, Python, PHP, Javascript). Don’t assume people have experience with other languages - it’s fine to present in them, but you may need to be ready to answer a few more questions.

• Members have some experience with a web framework.

• Members have basic knowledge of the command line.

• Members have used a version control system.

Who should not come?

We focus on teaching, learning, and technology, not recruiting. If your primary goal is to recruit engineers, there are other places to go.
results.name: Teach Us Something Technical: The Command Line

results.description:
It’s easy to see the value of Lean UX. Solving problems that have user value, validating assumptions before building anything … Sure! Makes sense. But how do you apply it to your work within a large enterprise? How can something born within small, co-located startups with easy access to users apply to your distributed corporate team in a monolithic organization?

Anthony Viviano has been practicing Lean UX within enterprises He will lay out his approach and share his own case study.

You’ll learn:
* The basics of Lean UX
* The different “tribes” within Lean UX
* The unique challenges that Enterprise UX teams face
* Why Lean UX is worthwhile within your organization
* How to introduce and practice Lean UX
﻿

Anthony Viviano is a mobile interaction designer at Bloomberg L.P., where he designs mobile interfaces that allow financial experts to perform tasks when not on their Bloomberg terminal.

Prior to Bloomberg, Anthony worked both as a consultant to large enterprises and embedded in design teams where he enjoyed tackling the most complex user interfaces on mobile and desktop. He’s helped companies such as TD Ameritrade, Chrysler Group, Hilton Worldwide, Kimberly Clark and General Motors.

As an interaction designer, Anthony applies design thinking to problem solving. He believes that better, more innovative solutions come out of a group and he uses Lean UX methods to facilitate collaboration. Anthony is a confident communicator, teacher and mentor. He holds a BS in Technical Communication, a Masters Certificate in Human Computer Interaction and is a Certified Usability Analyst by Human Factors International.

This event is co-promoted with the Digital Product Design and Software Product Management meetup groups.
results.name: Applying Lean UX in a Big Enterprise

results.description:
Join fellow technologists, entrepreneurs, and investors for the NY Enterprise Technology Meetup's (NYETM) June meetup on Wednesday 6/10/15 from 6:30pm-9:00pm!

[Note the new location: We're now hosting the meetup at Work-Bench]

For our June meetup we have some exciting companies demoing their technologies, including:


• Cockroach Labs - CockroachDB is a distributed, horizontally scalable database with transactional semantics, thus combining the best features of relational and NoSQL databases.  CockroachDB aims to bring the best aspects of Google's next generation database, Spanner, to the rest of the world via open source. Databases should scale horizontally with minimum fuss, survive disasters of all sorts including datacenter outages, and provide the right primitives so that developers can build applications, not workarounds. 


• Ravel Law - Ravel Law is a legal search, analytics, and visualization platform. Ravel enables lawyers to find, contextualize, and interpret information that turns legal data into legal insights. Ravel's array of powerful tools – which include data-driven, interactive visualizations and analytics – transforms how lawyers understand the law and prepare for litigation. In today's global and increasingly digital world, Ravel empowers attorneys to benefit from this huge influx of information and find value in it. 


• Confluent - Confluent offers a real-time data platform built around Apache Kafka. Apache Kafka, an open source technology created and maintained by the founders of Confluent, acts as a real-time, fault tolerant, highly scalable messaging system. It is widely adopted for use cases ranging from collecting user activity data, logs, application metrics, stock ticker data, and device instrumentation. Its key strength is its ability to make high volume data available as a real-time stream for consumption in systems with very different requirements—from batch systems like Hadoop, to realtime systems that require low-latency access, to stream processing engines that transform the data streams as they arrive. This infrastructure lets you build around a single central nervous system transmitting messages to all the different systems and applications within your company.

Sign up today, and if you have any questions, please contact Jon Lehr at [masked]. 


Looking forward to seeing you all soon!

Yours in collaboration,

results.name: June 2015 NY Enterprise Technology Meetup

results.description:
It’s easy to see the value of Lean UX. Solving problems that have user value, validating assumptions before building anything … Sure! Makes sense. But how do you apply it to your work within a large enterprise? How can something born within small, co-located startups with easy access to users apply to your distributed corporate team in a monolithic organization?

Anthony has been practicing Lean UX within enterprises He will lay out his approach and share his own case study.

You’ll learn:

* The basics of Lean UXThe different “tribes” within Lean UX
* The unique challenges that Enterprise UX teams face
* Why Lean UX is worthwhile within your organization
* How to introduce and practice Lean UX

Anthony is a mobile interaction designer at Bloomberg L.P., where he designs mobile interfaces that allow financial experts to perform tasks when not on their Bloomberg terminal.

Prior to Bloomberg, Anthony worked both as a consultant to large enterprises and embedded in design teams where he enjoyed tackling the most complex user interfaces on mobile and desktop. He’s helped companies such as TD Ameritrade, Chrysler Group, Hilton Worldwide, Kimberly Clark and General Motors.

As an interaction designer, Anthony applies design thinking to problem solving. He believes that better, more innovative solutions come out of a group and he uses Lean UX methods to facilitate collaboration. Anthony is a confident communicator, teacher and mentor. He holds a BS in Technical Communication, a Masters Certificate in Human Computer Interaction and is a Certified Usability Analyst by Human Factors International.

This event is co-promoted with the Lean Product Best Practices and Software Product Management meetup groups.
results.name: Applying Lean UX in a Big Enterprise

results.description:
Tickets are $20. Register here!

Need to raise a round? Join us on 6/10 as our experts discuss everything startups should know about fundraising approaches, investor relationships, and what makes a 'good' deal.

If your company is ready for your first (or second) round of fundraising, this is the perfect chance to learn everything you need to know to get started. We’ll discuss different types of investors, walk through debt and equity options and help you understand everything you’ll need to know on a term sheet. Our experts will equip you to navigate the world of venture capital, angel investors, and incubators, so you can be ready to seize financial opportunities.

Takeaways: - The difference between a deal you should take and a deal you should leave - How to structure relationships with investors - What types of terms are typical during a seed or Series A raise - Advantages and disadvantages of different fundraising approaches

Join us for pizza, drinks and insightful fundraising tips from our experts.

Guest Speakers:

Gary Ross, Priori Attorney</a>

<a href="http://www.galvanize.com/">Kate Shillo, VC and Director at Galvanize

Tickets are $20. Register here!

results.description:
We're going to redo the Daredevil meetup since we had to cancel it last time.

"In this retelling of the early career of The Man Without Fear, the Eisner Award-winning team of Jeph Loeb and Tim Sale have taken an inspiring action adventure story and blended it with a romantic comedy. The result is the heartwarming and heartbreaking story of two young people in love—Matthew Murdock and Karen Page." 

Buy it on Amazon or at Barnes & Noble


BONUS: If time allows, we will be watching the first episode of the Daredevil Netflix series

FOOD & DRINK
Stacy will provide some snacks and appetizers as well as bottles of water and Diet Coke. Bring cash to order pizza.


VENUE
Stacy's apartment at 210 E. 75th Street, Apt. 5B, between Second and Third Avenues. The building is on the south side of the street about half way down the block. It's across the street from a middle school gymnasium and fire station. Ring the buzzer for 5B to gain entrance and take the elevator to the 5th floor.

By subway: Take the 6 train to 77th Street and Lexington Avenue. Walk two blocks south and turn left onto 75th Street. Building is on 75th Street about half way between 2nd and 3rd Avenues.

By bus: Take the M101, M102 or M103 bus up Third Avenue and get off at 72nd Street. Walk three blocks north and turn right onto 75th Street. Building is on 75th Street about half way between 2nd and 3rd Avenues OR, take the M15 bus down Second Avenue and get off at 75th Street. Walk to 75th Street and head towards 3rd. Avenue (to your right if you are facing downtown).
results.name: Comic Book Club: 'Daredevil - Yellow' by Jeph Loeb & Tim Sale

results.description:
Cool new products <> cool product people. Bringing together New York's makers. 

This month's collection: Games

7:00 - 8:00pm  -  Founders share their experience building and growing their games. Less demos. More lessons learned. 

8:00 - 9:00pm - Meet fellow Product Hunters 

9:00pm - Drinks at Brass Monkey 

https://tctechcrunch2011.files.wordpress.com/2013/11/betaworks.jpg?w=400

Featured Gaming Hunts:

Founding Team of Product Hunt, Erik Torenberg (and surprise guest) 

Visiting us from San Francisco, Erik will tell us what's been happening at Product Hunt including a super secret special announcement (it has to do with games). 

Head of Marketing of Dots, Christian Calderon

Within two weeks of it's release in 2014, Dots users had played 100 million games. It won the 2014 Webby Award for best visual design. Hear the behind-the-scenes story of it's success. 

Co-founders of Killer Queen, Josh DeBonis & Nikita Mikros

What started as a real-world outdoor game in Brooklyn, became a unique 10-player arcade game. Killer Queen was recognized for excellence in design by the Independent Games Festival. 

Ideas for a collection next month? Tweet me. 

Disclaimer: This is a community organized event by Swig Labs. We're friends with Product Hunt guys but they're not directly organizing this event.
results.name: Product Hunt NYC: Games

results.description:
Explore electronics, coding, and creative technology at our monthly Micro-controller night. We talk about Arduinos, Raspberry Pis, and the other tiny devices we love to use for embedded projects. A laptop with a usb port is recommended in case you want to get hands on with any of the devices.

This event is free for everyone. Please bring a computer with a USB port, ideally bring one or more micro-controllers that you want to work with, or at least a project idea. Please share your ideas in the comments below to inspire others.

Boards are available online, or PM the organizer and they can either get one for you or tell you where they're cheapest online.

MakerBar volunteers will be present to help you with your electronics project or work on their own.

You're welcome to come hack on whatever you'd like, even if it's totally unrelated to electronics entirely. There will be plenty of awesome hackers from our community for you to meet.

The Microcontroller Special Interest Group runs on the second Wednesday every month.
results.how_to_find_us: Look for the red MakerBar sign and call to be let in.
results.name: Micro-Controller Special Interest Group

results.description:
I know a lot of you out there have wanted to try a Reiki treatment but private sessions are cost prohibitive to most so I have been trying to figure out how to bring you a group session. I finally found someone to work with me to bring in enough energy to benefit everyone. I am teaming up with Kris from Integrated Healing Therapies so that we can work together and do several people at once.

For those who don't know what Reiki is here is a good article on it: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reiki

It is a technique for channeling energy to individuals and to things to bring healing and to set intentions too. Maybe you suffer from headaches, or joint pain, perhaps depression or anxiety or stress from the job? Maybe you need more courage to find a better job, or you've been feeling sad lately. Reiki can virtually work on ANYTHING to improve your mind, body and soul!

So here's the plan, come to my house by 7pm (we can mingle some from 6:30-7 as people arrive) and bring $15 cash exact change please, wear something comfortable and if you want bring a light blanket to cover yourself with. We will get you comfortable and do some sharing and then do a guided meditation to relax you and then she and I will go around to each of you for a few minutes of focused energy to each of you to get you truly connected to the light.

I so look forward to sharing this with you!  Love, Cassie

If you can't make it, no need to post why. We understand and will catch you next time!
results.how_to_find_us: white house, black trim (GPS may say you are here 2 blocks too soon)
results.name: Group Reiki Session

Learn what the big agencies do and get some tips on how to apply them to scale for your start-up with some marketing insights from a seasoned advertising veteran who has worked on over 24 big name brands and countless small businesses and start-ups. This is a great tune-up session to help you figure out what your go-to-market strategy needs to be with scale in mind.

- Overview of marketing and advertising agency process
- What Media's roll is today and how it works
- Marketing and storytelling 101
- Q & A

More about the presenter-
David Urbano is a LaunchNJ community member. He owns a small boutique digital and video storytelling production consultancy called Viva! La Hara serving start-ups and small business based out of New Jersey in the finance technology, healthcare, green tech and non-profits sectors. He has produced web sites, video content and large marketing programs for over 25 major brands and brings a wealth of strategic insights with his experience.

Check out a recent article David shared on Linkedin-

results.description:
Mindful Astoria: Wednesday Meditation Gathering

Join us on Wednesday nights for meditation and conversation about mindfulness. Learn how to bring mindfulness into daily life, and how to establish, maintain, and deepen a personal mindfulness practice.

Each class will consist of instruction in different forms of mindfulness meditation, and time for group discussion and connecting with the community. Depending on the week, the teacher may give a talk or share a reading about a related topic.

Teacher for this night's gathering: Kimberly Brown

Kimberly Brown is a Meditation Teacher and the Executive Director of The Interdependence Project. She studies Tibetan and American Buddhism, and her teachers include Lama Norlha Rinpoche and Sharon Salzberg.  Her work and teachings emphasize the ways in which meditation, mindfulness, and ethics are shared among all traditions of awakening.  You can reach her at [masked].

Mindful Astoria

Every Wednesday, 7-8:30pm at the Astoria First Presbyterian Church.

All classes are drop-in, but RSVP. $5-$10 at the door to support the teachers, the Astoria Bookshop, and the Astoria Presbyterian Church. *Note that no one will be turned away for lack of funds. If you cannot afford the suggested donation, please give what you are able.

Email any questions to Emily Herzlin at [masked].

Looking forward to deepening practice and strengthening mindful community with you all!
results.how_to_find_us: The church is located at 23-35 Broadway, between Crescent St. and 23rd St. It is on the north side of Broadway, just past Trade Fair and Synergy Fitness. There is an awning over the front door. The church shares the space with Art House Astoria.
results.name: Mindful Astoria: Wednesday Meditation Gathering

Ask questions, receive healing, share your Reiki experiences, practice Reiki techniques, & exchange Universal Life energy with other healers! After a brief meditation and a talk or demo on a particular healing topic we will each take a healing turn on the table, followed by socializing over potluck snacks. Open to all who have been attuned to Reiki by an in-person Reiki Master. Space is limited, so if you RSVP and cannot show up, I am counting on you to un-RSVP as soon as you can to leave space for others.

results.description:
• Join us at the 4th WebRTC Summit, June 9-11, Javits Center 

WebRTC is the future of browser-to-browser communications, and continues to make inroads into the traditional, difficult, plug-in web communications world. 


The 4th WebRTC Summit continues our tradition of delivering the latest and greatest presentations within the world of WebRTC. Topics include voice calling, video chat, P2P file sharing, and use cases that have already leveraged the power and convenience of WebRTC. 

Note: the 4th WebRTC Summit is co-located with Cloud Expo East, to be held June 9-11 at the Javits Center. WebRTC Summit attendees will also have access to Cloud Expo during the entire three days of that event.


Speakers

• Natasha Tamaskar (Genband)

• Dr Alex Gouaillard (Temasys)

Agenda

7:00 p.m. - 7:30 p.m. Natasha Tamaskar (Genband) - 20min Keynote / 5-10min Q&A

7:30 p.m. - 8:00 p.m. Alex Gouaillard (Temasys) - 20min Keynote / 5-10min Q&A

8:00 p.m. - 8:30 p.m. Panel (Natasha Tamaskar, Alex Gouaillard, Arvind Rangarajan) moderate by Rob Spectre (Twilio)

8:30 p.m. - 9:00 p.m. Networking 

Venue

The WebRTC Meetup is in room 1A10.

results.description:
Join other writers for an hour of focused writing!

6-7 pm - Show up early, stake out a spot and either socialize or get a jump on writing.
7:00 - Start. Introductions, and we'll share what we're working on
7:05 - Get down to business. An hour of silence and solid writing!
8:05- Brief follow up. People are encouraged to share experiences & ideas, network or take off as they like. Feel free to keep writing if you've got the momentum going!

If you're spending too much time THINKING about writing, come and join us for a session of focused writing. It may just be "pipe-cleaning" for now, but you'll feel better showing up at the page. No one will see what you've written or give you unsolicited advice.

WHERE: David Rubenstein Atrium, 62nd and Broadway.

SOME TIPS:

Please, come on time! If you come late, we will have already started.
Bring headphones if you don't want outside noise distraction.

Please RSVP only if you can make it, and update as soon as possible if your plans change. We have had far too many no-shows.

You will see progress in your writing project by spending the minimum of a single hour per week on it. This is your practice/focus time, so I hope to see you there.
results.name: NYC Shut Up & Write Meetup! - Columbus Circle

results.description:
Hey New York SEO and Social Media Marketing Academy Meetup Fans:

Did you know?

80% of all adults now own a smartphone according to TechCrunch Magazine

50% of eCommerce traffic is coming from mobile

Mobile Digital Commerce is outpacing PC growth rates; therefore is is quintessential to learn about the how the advertising industry is shifting towards mobile/tablet with number of smartphone users at an all time high.

Mike Basch will speak about the Rise of Rich Media and how that will help drive your  eCommerce sales:

-Rich media’s role in the transition to mobile

-User acquisition using mobile for your eCommerce Site

-Why Spotad got into the marketplace of mobile advertising

-How to attain customers for your eCommerce site/app using mobile customizable add layouts

-How to target and optimize to your audience on mobile.

More about Mike Basch:

Having launched his career at the young age of 8 selling Lemonade for 25 cents a cup on the corner of his street in LA, he retains a hunger for business for as long as he can remember. With a background consisting of running over 20 coffee shops, building a global sourcing business, and finally landing in mobile ad tech, Michael knows how to build businesses across multiple industries and categories.

As it pertains to Spotad, Michael first got involved as an investor in the initial seed round in Mid-2013.  After being an active investor for a year, in Mid-2014, joined the business full-time, launching the US office--where they are looking to move the company headquarters to by end of 2015. You can connect with him on Linkedin here.

More about Spotad:

Spotad has an expertise in user acquisition as it pertains to mobile/tablet advertising, specifically for apps and e-commerce sites. In the rapidly growing world of advertising, Rich Media ads are the new spots everyone wants to tap into, while technology has been an obstacle for most advertisers. SpotAd removes this obstacle by using unique proprietary framework that enables every brand owner and marketers to deliver it’s own rich media ad in minutes.

To visit Spotad's Website: Spotad

The Meetup Structure:

7:00 - Short Networking

7:30 - We would love to hear 30 second of something about you from all our members

8:00 -Mike will be presenting with Q&A

8:35-9:30 We will be having networking  (For any Netsuite & Magento eCommerce related questions Sam Baron & Mai Erne from Hara Partners will be there to answer them)

Hope to see you all there!

Your fearless SEO & Social Media Marketing Academy leader,

Chanah

This Meetup is sponsored Hara Partners.

Check our Hara Partners: Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram pages!
results.name: How Mobile Advertising and Rich Media will drive your eCommerce Sales

To CJK Experts and Native Speakers:

We practice like this (including, but not limited to):

Session 1 (7pm-8pm): Interpretation methods practice

For example, words, phrases or sentences interpretation, target language repeating, shadowing and summarization, etc.

We set two tables to practice Chinese and Korean separately (Japanese is on hiatus due to low membership). The session is basically for intermediate & above Chinese and Korean learners.

Session 2 (8pm-9pm): Topic-based speaking practice

Summary, speak or discuss the topic you are provided or you have prepared by your target language (Chinese & Korean).

Also, everybody can move to any table as they want.

If you would like to practice English, please join our regular Saturday meetup generously hosted by Carl.

Looking forward to practicing with you all!

Organizers

results.description:
#ICPMEETUP | NEW BUSINESS MODELS IN PHOTOGRAPHY

In the last decade, the emergence and rise of digital imaging and the wealth of image supply it created has deeply changed the balance of power between photographer and buyer. Photo distribution is easier than ever and maintaining a position of 'never giving your work for free' is increasingly difficult as the internet offers photo editors almost infinite imagery to use. 

Selling work in the ‘fine arts’ world, and getting pre-financing for projects through traditional means has also become more difficult in this crowded and competitive context. 

From the revolution of crowdfunding to the new distribution, sales and licensing platforms leveling the field for aspiring and professional photographers alike, what solutions do exist for image-makers to make a living off their trade and properly monetize their stories and content?

Presented by Studio55 | @st55nyc.

Moderators

Ulli Barta and Fabrice Nadjari of Studio55 | @st55nyc

The brainchild of Ulli Barta and Fabrice Nadjari, Studio55 is a creative studio that conceives, initiates, consults, (re) positions, curates and connects. We create cultural content for unusual people.Panelists


Sara Walker | @shutterstock 


Sara is leading the global marketing efforts for Shutterstock’s contributors in the two-sided marketplace. She is an entrepreneurial, data-driven multi-channel digital marketer & strategist with a high aptitude for creating and executing multi-channel campaigns. She has previously worked for companies such as CAN Capital, Etsy and Motorola as a Digital Marketing Strategist.

Kenneth Schlenker | @artlistco @gertrwde

Kenneth is an entrepreneur passionate about shaping culture with technology. He is the co-founder and CEO of ArtList, an online marketplace for fine art whose mission is to make the global art market fast, secure and fair. On ArtList, collectors from around the world are selling hundreds of artworks by some of the most sought after artists today. Schlenker also started Gertrude, a startup whose mission is to connect people directly with artists at intimate events all over the world. Participants include The New Museum, The Guggenheim, Paula Cooper Gallery, Pace Gallery, Phillips Auction House, Frieze, Google, Tumblr and Faberge. Previously, Kenneth was at Google where he pioneered product and online advertising research with Fortune 500 companies. Kenneth serves as an advisor to several early stage startups and leading global universities. He has guest lectured at Princeton, Sciences Po, Parsons and Sotheby’s Institute. Kenneth graduated cum laude with a degree in Public Affairs and a masters in Finance from Sciences Po University in Paris.


Nur Elektra El Shami | @articurate

Nur is the co-founder and director of the international arts platform articurate.net. Prior to launching articurate.net in 2013, El Shami worked for several years in the luxury and fashion industry in Milan, Mumbai, New York, Paris and London for international companies such as Balmain and Mary Katrantzou. She holds a degree in cultural management and is fluent in English, Italian, German, and French. El Shami was inducted as a member of the European Cultural Parliament in 2014.
results.name: Learn about new business models in photography.
