results.description:
Global Mobile Internet Conference

The world’s most influential conference on mobile comes to New York City on June 11th. From Beijing to San Francisco and Tokyo to Bangalore, GMIC is the where the mobile community gathers to learn about the latest innovations and connect with industry thought leaders. 

Creating a deeper engagement with your customers via mobile is key. GMIC New York will address the unique challenges and opportunities that brands using mobile experience everyday. Come explore the future of mobile for entertainment, retail, media, brands, agencies and consumer products to get a clear perspective on how to optimize the mobile customer experience. In just one day at GMIC, you'll learn how to harness the power of mobile to strengthen brand loyalty, increase customer engagement and deliver personalized customer experiences. 

RSVP: Please purchase your ticket and RSVP via below link: http://nyc.thegmic.com

As a partner of GMIC New York station, NYCCEO will bring to our members 2 types of discount/benefit on tickets. In order to better understand our member requirements, we invite you to fill out a short questionnaire. After completing the survey, not only can you get 30% off promotion code on all GMIC tickets, you also have the opportunity to win a $ 1099-worth VIP Pass. This promotion event ends June 9. NYCCEO reserves the right of final interpretation. 

Participation Procedures: 

1. Go to http://goo.gl/forms/lRcCWE39kt and complete a NYCCEO Membership Survey

2. Submit the questionnaire to see a 30%-off promotion code

3. NYCCEO will draw lucky members who filled out the survey and announce the winners on June 9

More about GMIC and GWC

GMIC (Global Mobile Internet Conference) annually hosts tens of thousands of mobile executives, entrepreneurs, developers, and investors from around the globe and across platforms to build partnerships, to learn from industry thought leaders, to better understand mobile technology trends, and to highlight how mobile is positively changing the world. Hosted and produced by GWC.


The GWC Membership ---- an invitation-only, private network for innovators and executives from leading mobile companies worldwide to build trusted relationships, share insights, explore collaboration and develop international growth strategy.

About NYCCEO

Founded in 2012 as a meetup group, NYCCEO is the gateway between US and China entrepreneurship, and becomes one of the most influential organizations serving the entrepreneur community in New York. We help startups with fundraising, talent recruiting, and strategic introductions. We have monthly events in diverse formats focusing on entrepreneurship. Since established, we have collaborated with many leading Venture Capital funds and technology giants, and built up a strong relationship with them. The guest speakers in our network include Shunwei Capital, Zhenfund, Xiaomi, Amazon, Google, Jet.com, China United Network Communications Group, Great Wall Club (GWC), etc. NYCCEO currently has over 1000 talents from New York, including Finance, IT, Fashion, Designing.

NYCCEO is one of the most influential organizations serving the entrepreneur community in New York. For more activities in New York and China, please add NYCCEO wechat public account @NYCCEO or scan the following QR code directly.
results.name: NYCCEO Partnered Global Mobile Internet Conference - Win a Free VIP Pass

results.description:
Join us, one and all, for our Pitch Deck Teardown! You'll get to present your Pitch to 3 awesome NY Tech Scene mentors, and get immediate and actionable feedback. Feel free to join us as well, if you're working on your own pitch, or just want to meet great people. Also, we are collecting submissions for those that wanna pitch: http://bit.ly/1divwEf


The format:
  • 5 mins pitch
  • 5 min Q&A
  • 5 min panel feedback

Details for Thursday, 6/11
The inaugural event is free!
Mentors:

Jay Melone

Jay is the CEO and co-founder of New Haircut, a digital agency based out of NJ. Before New Haircut, he had a 14 year career as a digital product strategist, business analyst, project manager and software engineer.
Jay started his tech career as a programmer within Accenture, and after 8 years, he left to become the Director of Project Planning at a startup called Partsearch Technologies. Before venturing out on his own, his last corporate gig was as a Sr. Project Manager at a financial services company called Tradition. Finally, in 2010, Jay connected with his current business partner, John Vetan. Together, they created New Haircut.
New Haircut is a creative web agency that helps create your visual identity (logos, print work, pitch decks, brochures, etc) before moving on to design and build your websites and mobile apps. They’ve worked with dozens of startups, along with a bunch of companies already wearing their big boy & big girl pants.
Jay spends most of his working hours educating entrepreneurs and company executives on the best ways to apply web, mobile and social solutions to their new or growing venture.

John Lynn

John is founder of an accelerator-backed company, a Techstars Associate, and current Program Manager of Startup Institute New York. An active connector in the community, he has engineered LP investments for venture capital funds, the creation of a Techstars company, angel investment for a mentor's new venture, and brokered co-founder relationships and first hires.
An early alumni of Startup Institute, John is inspired by people who put their heart into everything they do, listens almost exclusively to Arcade Fire and M83, and loves tennis and writing short fiction.
As Program Manager of SINYC, he helps design and evaluate the accelerator experience, curate its mentor community, and deliver curriculum content.

Shawn Cheng

Shawn Cheng is a Principal at Vayner/RSE, Gary Vaynerchuk’s Venture Captial firm. Prior to joining he worked in Strategy, Digital Advertising, Social Media and Search at Razorfish, BBDO and VaynerMedia for 10 years. He has worked on dozens of brands such as, Mondelez, GE, Mondelez, Starwood Hotels and Victoria’s Secret.
He has been a startup mentor for three years through the Entrepreneurs Roundtable Accelerator and helped to create dozens of emerging tech partnerships and programs.

results.description:
Learn How to Create the Look of Common Light Sources, 

Both Natural and Artificial

When working on narrative films, a DP will often need to create light for their scene that replicates environmental sources such as window light, moonlight, campfire, street lamps or even a nightlight in a bedroom. Join Daniel Norton On Set as we walk through techniques to create realistic scenes with professional lighting, as well as some DIY solutions.

Direction, color and quality of the light falling on your subject often defines the time of day and location of your scene to the viewer. By studying light sources we can create the look and feel of just about any time of day or location that you can imagine.

LEARN: How to create window light that feels like morning and night.
LEARN: How to use lighting gels to create the feel of street lamps and "ugly" florescent sources.
LEARN: How to Build a light the replicates the flicker and color of FIRE! 

During this workshop we will light and shoot several quick scenes and photos to illustrate each lighting technique. From moonlight to a bedside lamp, morning sun to candlelight, we will cover a wide range of scenarios.

There will be three distinct sessions, come for one, come for all!
Sessions start at 12pm, 2pm and 4pm. 

All in attendance will be given a coupon for $25 off your next purchase of $250.
results.name: FREE EVENT: OnSet Day: Replicating Existing Light for Photo and Video

This meetup is for professionals working in nonprofits or anyone interested in networking within the nonprofit industry.

Those meetups are organized by bitCharities and held twice per month in BitCharities office in Manhattan, NY.

What is bitCharities? www.bitcharities.com
bitCharities democratizes charitable giving by connecting brands, non-profits and donors.
bitCharities.com gathers large scale data on its entire user and donor base and shares it at no cost with the participating charities so that they can scale their fundraising efforts with larger corporate sponsors.
bitCharities gives back 100% of the donations gathered on its platform to the charities.
While donors can easily, simply, and publicly support a wide range of charitable organizations, brands can align their philanthropic efforts with their customers. bitCharities can engage the first party brand's database and activate them to participate in charitable donations, creating global awareness and a call for action even before any money is spent.

results.description:
Rutgers Landscape Architecture Students Take On Jersey City!
Local Environmental Groups Sponsor Exhibits at Casa Colombo

Two exhibits of Rutgers student work on Jersey City infrastructure and landmarks are at the Center for the Arts at Casa Colombo from June 11th until August 27th.  Environmental Resources and Issues: Investigations of Environmental Solutions for Jersey City is in Gallery 2. Building Studies: An Archive of Jersey City Architecture is in Gallery 3.

The student work was originally shown for one evening at a Jersey City Environmental Commission meeting. Now several local environmental groups are partnering with Rutgers to broaden opportunities to engage the public and to inspire greater input from citizens to City officials about the changing landscape of Jersey City.

Reception and Viewing Hours

An opening reception is set for Thursday, June 11, 2015, from 5-8 pm, at Casa Colombo, 380 Monmouth St, Jersey City. Eldad Tarmu, vibraphonist / composer, will be performing.

The program schedule is as follows:

5 pm  Doors open for viewing exhibits in Gallery 2 and 3

6 pm  Music and refreshments in Gallery 2

6:30  Welcome from organizers in Gallery 2

6:45  Opening remarks by Rutgers curators

7:30  Questions and discussion

Following the opening, the exhibits are viewable during regular museum hours, which are Tuesdays and Thursdays, 10am – 3pm, and at additional special events and times to be scheduled over the summer. A closing reception is scheduled for Thursday evening, August 27. See Sustainable JC’s website for updates on summer programming (http://www.SustainableJC.org).

Exhibit Details

•  Environmental Resources and Issues is the outcome of an environmental resource study that resulted in maps showing the complex quilt of cultural, historic, civic, and natural resources of Jersey City.  These maps, plus research and interviews, resulted in an analysis of Jersey City and its history.  The analysis led to six sets of speculative design proposals that students developed to address issues such as pedestrian safety, transportation nodes, and environmental infrastructure. These proposals focused on The Heights, Journal Square, Downtown Jersey City, the West Side, and Greenville neighborhoods.


• Building Studies is one result of a study of seventeen landmark buildings in Jersey City. The exhibit is a set of detailed measured drawings, showing the four facades and, when possible, a generalized floor plan, for each building.  In addition, three-dimensional studies allow for views of the buildings that highlight unique characteristics.

Many of the buildings studied are listed on the State and/or National Registers of Historic Places. These include the Central Railroad of New Jersey Terminal (1889), the only survivor of Jersey City’s magnificent waterfront passenger rail terminals; Continental Can Company Complex (Canco Lofts), a factory-to-loft conversion project; Fairmount Apartments, an early-20th-century apartment building in the Arts and Crafts style; Hudson and Manhattan Powerhouse, the 1908 Romanesque Revival structure that once powered what is now the PATH; William J. Brennan Hudson County Courthouse, an early historic preservation success; Ionic House (Dr. William Barrow Mansion), an 1837 Greek Revival building; Loew’s Theatre, the 1929 Baroque-style movie theatre; Old Bergen Reformed Church, an 1841 building that houses a congregation that has met since Dutch colonial days; Stanley Theatre, the massive, ornate 1928 movie theater; Van Wagenen (Apple Tree) House, the 1750 home in which General George Washington and the Marquis de Lafayette were believed to have met.

The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company Warehouse is not only on the State and National Registers, but is also a National Landmark.

Other landmarks treated are Jersey City’s 1889 City Hall; Goldman Sachs Tower, the state’s tallest building when it was completed in 2004; the National Guard Armory, a beaux arts building completed in 1937; St. Anne’s, a 1903 church; Temple Beth-El, the 1926 home of a liberal congregation that has met since the Civil War period; and New Jersey City University (NJCU) Arts and Sciences Building.

Exhibit Curators and Sponsors

This undergraduate student work was developed under the supervision of Rutgers University faculty Jean Marie Hartman, Ph.D., David C. Smith, M.S., and Anita Bakshi, Ph.D., from the Department of Landscape Architecture, during semester-long Design Lab courses (Environmental Planning Studio and Visualization III-CAD for Landscape Architects) focused on Jersey City.

Sponsors of the current show are are Rutgers University School of Environmental and Biological Sciences, Rutgers University Department of Landscape Architecture, Rutgers CUES, Sustainable Jersey City, Embankment Preservation Coalition, Historic Jersey City & Harsimus Cemetery, and Jersey City Parks Coalition. Special thanks go to Sidney Montanez of SDesigns and Alina Tarmu of The Art Garden Shed.

The sponsors hope the exhibits will help to educate visitors and spark a wider discussion among Jersey City residents about our city’s built assets and the options for future development, while encouraging these young students and future landscape architects in their public-spirited pursuits.

Additional Programming

Additional programming on topics of interest is being planned, and suggestions from the public are invited – please send to [masked]  Topics already suggested include Landscape Architectural Sketch Walks, Urban Forestry, and Soil Structure and Remediation of Heavy Metals for Open Spaces.

Please RSVP For Opening Reception (required) here; suggested donation $5.00

Download Promotional Flyer here.

Many of my members do bring guests here and everyone does have a good time.

results.description:
AKQA presents The State of Apps 2015

As traffic from mobile applications continues to grow, its clear apps are becoming the dominant way users are accessing the internet. As a result, the options for developers to produce and manage applications continues to evolve. At this event, our speakers will discuss the various options developers have to build apps, and engage with users.

If interested in attending this Meetup, we will be using this link to keep track of attendees, so please register here:

http://www.techinsight.io/event/newyork-june-2015/#tickets

Food, beer, and other beverages will be served!

Blurring the Lines
Brian Fegan, AKQA
The popularity of JavaScript continues to grow, and browsers continue to release standards-based APIs which leverage device hardware. In this session, AKQA’s Associate Director of Creative Development will discuss how it’s becoming increasingly difficult to determine the differences between native, web & hybrid apps.

Engineering Engagement
Matt McRoberts & Spencer Burke, AppBoy
This session provides insight into how to move beyond the download and guide app consumers from initial acquisition into an ongoing dialogue; enabling engagement at an individual level.

Instant App Distribution
Kenny Lin, AKQA
In this session, we'll explore how AKQA is using a hybrid shell as an app distribution platform; something that can only be accomplished with a hybrid app. Senior Creative Developer Kenny Lin will demonstrate how to leverage a CMS, a hybrid app shell, and web sockets to push instant UI and content updates to multiple devices.

The AKQA TECH.insight mission is to create a community and code platform to inspire and facilitate invention with software.
results.name: AKQA NY TECH.insight

Who is this for?

Stretch and Strength is a great class for people seeking a lower intensity class as a part of their fitness strategy.

A great addition/ supplemental class for high intensity "Achievers".

Great for beginning exercisers to build a strong base of core, balance and support to enable them to live with less pain and improve functions of daily living.

A great class for GOLFERS. Golf Fitness will improve your felxibility and balance and power to increase clubhead speed and reduce post round pain.

A fantastic class for high intensity exercisers (Cross Fitness, Rev, Runners) to insure they maintain proper muscle balance.

Stretch and Strength combines Yoga and Pilates moves, Balance Training and Dyanamic Flexibility exercises to insure your body maintains the proper muscle balance to help prevent injuries and increase core strength.

results.description:
***FAST NIGHT HIKE, NOT FOR BEGINNERS***

Make sure you have a copy of the map, a headlamp, and 1 liter of water, minimum.  If you fall behind during the hike, you must be prepared to finish on your own.  Faster hikers are not obligated to wait for slower hikers. Since we will be exiting at/after dusk, you must feel comfortable hiking out on your own should you fall behind.

We will be ascending Major Welch and descending on the AT.  People who have done the Breakneck Bypass Loop will find the ascent on Major Welch to be comparatively strenuous, but the descent on the AT to be much more pleasant.

Heavy rain cancels and would be determined that day if necessary.

Distance: about 4 miles

Gain: about 1200

Hike time: 2+ hours

Map:  http://www.visitbearmountain.com/files/603/BearMountainTrailMap.pdf

This hike offers  outstanding views up and down the Hudson River and the Bear Mountain Bridge.

*** possible parking fee *** It would be $8 if there's still an attendant at that hour, but that's doubtful

Please don't be late - we start on time.  We will meet in the main lot close to the Bear Mountain Inn.

++

NOTE: You are responsible for bringing appropriate gear, supplies, clothing, first aid, and lights. You should review topographic maps and trail features carefully; understanding topography of any hike is key to your knowing where you are, where you're going, and how to get back. See suggestions for GEAR on the "About" page for additional gear ideas.

You agree when you sign up for this group or any of the events that you have read and understand the below.

If you join us for a hike (or any other event), please understand that you are responsible for your own preparedness and well-being and will hold no one else liable in case of injury or mishap. You agree not to hold the Organizer, Assistant Organizers, or any other members responsible for any injuries, mishaps, or any other situation that may happen at a planned event. You are responsible to research the event, know the area, and bring the proper gear.

Your attendance on a hike signifies that you have read and accept the terms of this liability waiver. Full waiver can be found on the ABOUT page.
results.name: Bear Mountain *SUNSET HIKE*

results.description:
Meet me at Central Park for a guided meditation. That means you don't have to do anything except for show up and be ready to leave feeling happy and peaceful! Bring something to sit on if you mind sitting directly on the grass.

I will lead you through a meditation which will bring awareness to your body, mind and soul. We will release any limiting beliefs and practice diaphragmatic breathing. We will work through the 7 chakras and raise your energy, releasing any blockages in your energy field. 


We will meet at the southern end of Sheep Meadow, by the giant rock. You can't miss it. If you need help finding us, please call me at <a>[masked]</a>. Please leave a donation after the meditation. It helps me keep the group going. Average donations are $10-$20.

Love,

Rina
results.name: Meditation at Central Park

results.description: Presented by the Lapidus Center for the Historical Analysis of Transatlantic Slavery), this new book looks at the maroons "all over the Americans who led secret lives - secluded in the forests, the swamps and the mountains while fiercely maintaining their independence. A great lineup of speakers is planned: Omar H. Ali (Benkos Bioho, African Maroon Leadership in New Grenada), Sylviane A. Diouf (author of Slavery's Exiles: The Story of the American Maroons), and Richard Price (author of Travels with Tooy: History, Memory and the African American Imagination). A book signing will follow the discussion. On Friday at 6 p.m., come back for a documentary film: Akwantu: The Journey, chronicling the struggle for freedom of the Maroons of Jamaica. Shot in Jamaica, Ghana, Canada the the U.S. and features interviews with renowned scholars, Maroon officials and present-day Jamaican residents.
results.name: Maroons Revisted: History and Stories... a reading and book signing

results.description:
Manhattan Toastmasters' General Meeting is scheduled for Thursday, June 11, 2015. We would like to welcome guests to attend this meeting. You will get to experience awesome speeches by our Manhattan Toastmasters Club members as well gain some experience speaking in front of a group. 

Our meetings are divided into three sections. The first section is project speeches, delivered by our Club Members. The second section is Table Topics, where Club Members and Guests get a chance to practice impromptu speaking. Third and final section are Evaluations when the project speakers receive constructive feedback from the evaluators. 

Come and join us for our General meeting and take the first step in improving your public speaking skills, gain confidence and make new friends who will support and encourage you.

AFTER-PARTY immediately after the meeting we will socialize at The Upstairs Pub located on the 2nd Floor of Everyday Gourmet Cafe (corner of 41st & Lexington)
results.name: June 11, General Meeting

group.name: Manhattan Toastmasters - Learn, Speak, Overcome, & Achieve

results.description:
Twitter:  @NycDataSci

Learn with our NYC Data Science Program (We've offered corporate and individual training to more than 40 firms in NYC alone). We offer 12 week immersive program, weekend and weekday night Data Science training.

Join the open house to learn more about our 12-Week Data Science bootcamp. (Apply before Deadline May 6th.)

Come to check out our new campus and bootcamp classroom.

====================================

The Founder of the school, Vivian Zhang, along with the COO, Janet Kamin, will be hosting. 

You're Invited! Save the date. Come have an after-work drink with members of the NYC Data Science community. Learn how you can bring your data scientist goals to life.

Drop in any time between 6:00 - 8:00 pm!

Meet our instructors, alumni, and staff. Learn what it means to be a Data Science student, and check out our alumni's final projects. Get introductions to our upcoming course offerings or have a 1-on-1 chat with our admissions rep to find the right course for you. Learn about the NYC Open Data Group, NYC Data Science Academy and the benefits of becoming a member of the school and meetup!

Have questions? Need help with something you are working on? Come check out NYC Data Science Academy's weekly office hours! Our talented teachers will be on hand to help and answer your questions. If you have specific question, please leave it in the comment section. So we can get prepared to help you out!
results.name: 12-Week Data Science Bootcamp - Open House

results.description:
We are holding a fundraiser for our kids to compete in a national programming contest. Come meet new people and learn more about BDPA and some of the programs that are helping kids in our communities. Come and meet the kids who will be competing in this years High School Computer Competition. Food and drinks will be served.

Throughout the year, local chapters conduct SITES training programs for the youth in their communities. These programs are designed to expose our youth to the concepts of computers and give them the expertise to develop web applications.

Some chapters will participate in regional competitions throughout the country to further prepare their students. Each BDPA chapter is able to send one team of 3 to 5 students to the National Conference to compete against teams from chapters all over the country. 

The BDPA National High School Computer Competition, (HSCC), was founded in 1986 by Dr. Jesse Bemley, of Washington, D.C. What started as a two-team event between Washington, D.C. and Atlanta, Ga. has grown to over 20 teams of various high school students from chapters throughout the nation. It's all designed to introduce our Youth to the field of Information Technology, encourage them to seek higher levels of education, and groom many of them to become our next generation of IT professionals.   

If you can not attend and wish to donate to the students, use the following link:

http://www.gofundme.com/BDPANY-HSCC

Feel free to contact me if you have any questions. Thank you for your support.

results.description:
As seen in the CNBC Documentary The Bitcoin Uprising.


Enter “The Nakamoto Circle of All Satoshi Squares” aka the World’s Largest Direct Sellers-to-Buyers Bitcoin Trading Pit! 

Thursdays are the new Saturdays as Satoshi Saturday is breaking for summer! Thursday will feel like Monday night at 40 Broad Street although the event will begin a bit later. 

Starting at 7:00 p.m. Bitcoin Center NYC welcomes Satoshi Square for a night of spontaneous Bitcoin trading in a LIVE open outcry trading pit. Buy or sell Bitcoins with Satoshi Square and others, or just observe and enjoy a party among fellow Bitcoin enthusiasts. Open bar!

This event is perfect for expert and novice traders as well as exhibitors, vendors, hardware and software developers, educators, students, media, and anyone wanting to be acquainted with the technology. Talk to our experts and get feedback concerning Bitcoin-related startups, as we are an incubator for these. Gaze upon MiningBot and Cash2BTC, two examples of path-breaking Bitcoin hardware the center co-developed. Meet or become a center sponsor and get exposure among the right audience and media!

No matter the focus of your Bitcoin interest or your expertise level, you are welcome. Bring a friend who might have read or heard something about Bitcoin. With our assistance he or she will leave with a better understanding and their first electronic or paper wallet. 

All trading is organic, spontaneous, and occurs directly between sellers and buyers. There are no intermediaries, and no fees as we are neither a trading floor nor a brokerage. Drinks and hospitality are courtesy of Bitcoin Center NYC. 


Details follow. See you there!


Every Thursday Night


7:00 p.m. to 11:00 p.m.

World’s Largest Direct Sellers-to-Buyers Trading Pit aka

‘The Nakamoto Circle of All Satoshi Squares’

Bitcoin Center NYC

40 Broad Street

New York, NY 10004


For a map of Bitcoin Center NYC, click here. 

Find Bitcoin Center NYC on Facebook, LinkedIn, Meetup, and Twitter.

All guests of Bitcoin Center NYC are required to sign in.  Media must RSVP using [masked].

If you are viewing this page on the Meetup app click the description tab to view the list of galley openings.  


If you are using an Android mobile browser and don't see the images on this page then open your browser's settings menu and click ''Request Desktop Site". 

With Apple IOS simply click the desktop site button at the bottom of the page. 

And finally :) For those new to the Hop you might be wondering how you will find the group. Well below is a lovely pictures of myself. Study my face carefully and commit it to memory. Now that I am burned into your hippocampus simply look for me hovering near the entrance to the first gallery.

Every week I receive emails from new members asking if there is a fee to join or attend the Thursday Night Gallery Hop. So rather than answer each email individually I'll kill a whole flock of birds with one stone. 

THE HOP IS, ALWAYS HAS BEEN, AND WILL REMAIN COMPLETELY FREE

That said if you would like to help offset my organizer fees or buy me a post-hop bourbon you are more than welcome to click the 'chip in' button on the left side of this page. But let me reiterate contributions while appreciated are NOT required. 

And now the openings...


Danjerus Cable

Tegene Kunbi 

Margaret Thatcher Projects - 539 West 23rd Street

Dancing with Dystopia


Robert Arneson, Dan Basen, David Beck, Barton Benes, Kathy Calderwood, César, Linda Cross, Peter Dean, Juan Gonzalez, Susan Goodrich, James Grashow, Richard Haden, Sharon Kopriva, Joseph Kurhajec, Robert Mallary, Jerry McLaughlin, Robert Neuman, Wayne Nowack, Bill Pellicone, Robert Rasely, Richard Rosenblum, Luis Saez, and Jack Whitten


Allan Stone Projects -535 W 22nd Street, 3rd Floor - 

Raw Beauty 

Bradley Theodore and Antoine Verglas


ACA Galleries - 529 West 20th Street, 5th Floor

Four new exhibitions


Andres Galeano; Jorunn Hancke Øgstad and Tyra Tingleff; Random International; and The Studio Chronicles

RH Contemporary Art - 437 West 16th Street


Grand Opening


Ayla Hibri, Jesse Draxler, Ken Silver, Louise Mertens, Martin Rinman

FOTOFOAM - 402 West 13th Street


After the openings (around 9pm) everyone who would like to continue with the group are welcome to join us at a nearby restaurant (location TBD) for refreshments and general merriment.   

Look forward to seeing everyone

Todd

results.description:
Please join us for a fireside chat with Matt Weinberg, President of Vector Media Group on Thursday, June 11th from 6 - 8pm.

Vector Media Group is an interactive digital agency located in the heart of the Flatiron District of New York City. They are dedicated to sharing their expertise in Web and Mobile Development, Design, and Marketing to help build powerful tools and campaigns that work. Their award-winning teams employ business standards with ethical best practices that drive brand growth.

Matt is the President of Vector Media Group Inc. With over a decade of experience building technology solutions for Vector’s clients, Matt leads the technical planning, execution and delivery in all projects. He is an expert in blending the latest technical advances with a pragmatic approach, and has developed sites ranging from large publishing platforms to customized eCommerce stores.


Fireside chat format:


• 6:00 - 6:30 pm: Open Networking

• 6:30 - 7:15 pm: Fireside Chat using a Q&A approach, (35mins between speaker and organizer, and 10mins between speaker and audience)

• 7:15 - 8:00 pm: Open Networking

Contribution - $5 with your RSVP online; $10 in-person

Wine and snacks will be served.  Can't wait to see you there!

Have a great idea for a guest speaker?  Please let us know!

results.description:
Updated March 8th, 2015

This is one of three sites/listserves that promotes weekly games that have been going on for many many years. Stall counts are used on occasion, cleats are optional, boundaries are flexible, and all skill levels are welcome!

There are two ways to stay in touch outside of Meetup.com:

- Follow us on Twitter: http://www.twitter.com/nycultimate
- Like us on Facebook: http://www.facebook.com/nycultimate

SPRING/SUMMER (Mar - Aug)

As the city warms up we play four times a week. Our main location is Riverside Park, with Morningside as a backup.

There are four days that we play:

- Saturdays at 10am, Riverside Park (103rd and West End)
- Sundays at 1pm, Riverside Park (103rd and West End)
- Tuesdays at 6pm, Riverside Park (103rd and West End - Where we can!)
- Thursdays at 6pm, Riverside Park (103rd and West End - Where we can!)

Damien
[masked]

RIVERSIDE DETAILS

The Riverside location is all the way West just off the water between 102nd and 108th Streets. You can only enter the park at 103rd and 108th. The best way to get there is to take the 1 local to 103rd Street. Walk West until you see an entrance that takes you down to the fields through the park. After walking down the steps from the street, you will see a path that goes left and another that goes right. Walk down the left path until you see a stone wall and stairs that go down to the fields. From South to North there will be one small soccer field surrounded by a track (red 'A' on map), another field with two softball fields (closer to 103rd/104th st) and another that is a giant soccer field (closer to 106th st). After walking down the steps, you will see the small Soccer field on your left. Start from this Southern-most field and walk North on the path to find our game. If you see no one, the meeting spot is the South side of the large soccer field. This spot is identified on the map below, a small square with little dots around it. On days when we can't find space at Riverside, we will move the game to Morningside Park (West 110th St and Manhattan Ave).

MORNINGSIDE DETAILS

The Morningside location is at the corner of 110th Street and Manhattan Avenue. The best way to get there is to take the B or C local to 110th Street. You can also take the 1 train to 110th street at Broadway and then walk East. We will play at the South end of the baseball field parallel to 110th street so that we're not in the way of the baseball games. Riverside will be our backup if for some reason we need to change locations.

+++

OTHER SEASONS...

WINTER (Nov - Feb)

During the colder months we generally play two times a week depending on weather. Our main location is Riverside Park with Morningside as a backup.

There are two days that we play:

- Saturdays at 10am, Riverside Park (108th and West End - Big Soccer Field)
- Sundays at 1pm, Riverside Park (108th and West End - Big Soccer Field)
*Tuesdays/Thursdays at 6pm games don't last long due to decreasing sunlight.

FALL (Sep - Oct)

There are four days that we play:

- Saturdays at 10am, Morningside Park (110th and Manhattan Ave)
- Sundays at 4pm, Riverside Park (103rd and West End)
- Tuesdays at 5:30pm, Riverside Park (103rd and West End)
- Thursdays at 5:30pm, Riverside Park (103rd and West End)

results.description:
• Great intro to Arduino

• Shows some of the capabilities of the Arduino

• Self paced, ask questions as you play !

• Continue where you left off last Class 



This is a fully hands on class. Just connect your Arduino and we will walk through example code together. This class will focus on getting you up and running with Arduino quickly, so that you can begin to explore the world of Arduino on your own.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YCqFHuyT7qc

This class will be run using the Basic Kit by Sain Smart which can be purchased for $25.00, so you can continue to work on  projects at home.  See below for details. 

We can also provide you with a Sparkfun’s Inventor Kit which will be available for use during the session.

Examples & PDF can be found here: Zip file with PDF instructions & Example code with Data sheets

We will be walking through the following example codes


Circuit Examples:

Circuit 1: Blinking an LED

Circuit 2: Reading a Potentiometer

Circuit 3: Driving and RGB LED

Circuit 4: Driving Multiple LEDs

Circuit 5: Push Buttons

Circuit 6: Reading a Photo Resistor

Circuit 7: Reading a Temperature Sensor

Circuit 8: Driving a Servo Motor

Circuit 9: Using a Flex Sensor

Circuit 10: Reading a Soft Potentiometer

Circuit 11: Using a Buzzer

Circuit 12: Driving a Motor

Circuit 13: Using Relays

Circuit 14: Using a Shift Register

Circuit 15: Using an LCD

Circuit 16: Simon Says


Before the Workshop

Please bring your laptop. Arduino runs on Windows, Mac OSX, and Linux. Download the (free) Arduino software prior to the workshop from http://arduino.cc/en/Main/Software, and install as much as you can. Instructions at http://arduino.cc/en/Guide/HomePage

*A limited number of laptops will be provided if you choose not to bring your own.

*An Arduino kit will be provided for use during the workshop or you may bring your own. Purchase your own kit to take home, see details below.

If you have questions prior to or after the workshop please contact the instructor Brian Cook @  [masked]


We will also be selling small basic kits if you would like to purchase your own. Here are the kits we will have available. Please bring cash or check for the materials if you would like to purchase your own kit. Please RSVP with the specific board you would like so we can make sure enough kits are purchased. We have attached the link to the kits for more information and to take a look at what's included or specific specs for each kit.

results.description:
Only $90 for the entire 8 week semester! Please email or message el centro to confirm we are still accepting students before coming to this class. 

In the Level 3 Spanish class students will already have a working knowledge, but more advanced capacity, in the basics of conversation. At this level students will be expected to have gained the ability to read and write simple sentences. The main objectives of Level 3 will be to improve fluidity, improve vocabulary and improve overall understanding of spoken and written Spanish. After one term in level 3 students will be prepared for basic and brief conversations. After two terms in level 3 students will have finished with the a more advanced conversational ability in anticipation of the level 4 environment. 

En la clase de Nivel 3 de español, alumnos ya tendrán un conocimiento práctico pero mas avanzado en cuanto los conceptos básicos de conversación.  En éste nivel se esperará que los estudiantes han obtenido la capacidad de leer y escribir oraciones simples.  Los principales objetivos del nivel 3 serán mejorar la fluidez de los estudiantes, mejorar el vocabulario y mejorar la comprensión general del español hablado y escrito.  Después de un semestre en el nivel 3 los estudiantes estarán preparados para conversaciones básicas y breves.  Después de dos semestres en el nivel 3 los alumnos terminaran con la capacidad para conversaciones y comunicaciones escritas mas avanzadas en anticipación al ambiente del nivel 4.
results.name: Spanish 3 - Intermediate Conversational Spanish

results.description:
COME BREAK UP THE WORK WEEK AND JOIN US FOR A SUNSET MOUNTAIN BIKE RIDE AT MOHONK PRESERVE.

Please arrive by 6:15pm at the West Trapps Parking Lot to allow time to prep your bike and gear so that we may depart promptly by 6:30pm.

Starting from the West Trapps Lot we will Follow Undercliff Road to the Rhododendron Bridge.  We will cross over and take a right onto Oakwood Drive.  Next we take a sharp left onto Kleine Kill Road, then a left on Forest Drive, another left on Lake Shore Road and a right onto Long Woodland Drive which will take us to Humpty Dumpty Lane.

At Humpty Dumpty Lane we will stop at one of the Gazebos and take in the breathtaking views before our descent down Laurel Ledge Road and head back to West Trapps via Overcliff Road.

Please note: Our route may change slightly depending on the groups abilities, remaining daylight and enthusiasm levels. The addition of Duck Pond is an option that will cover more elevation if the group is up to it.


Distance: Approximately 12-13 miles

Estimated Bike Time: 2 hours

Difficulty: Advanced Beginner / Intermediate - Gravel Carriage Roads with some Steep Hills

Current Weather Forecast: Partly Sunny with a high of 91 degrees

 MANDATORY GEAR:

• Mountain Bike or Hybrid

• Bicycle Helmet

• Headlamp with spare batteries

RECOMMENDED GEAR:

• Clear eye Protection (safety glasses - for bugs, dirt, etc.)

• Related maps, a compass or GPS, Water, Snacks, First Aid, etc.

• Bike Pump

• Tire Patch Kit and/or Spare Tube

PLEASE INSPECT YOUR BIKE PRIOR TO ARRIVAL TO INSURE THE FOLLOWING:

• Proper Tire Inflation

• Lubricated chain

• Properly Shifting gears

• Functional Brakes that don't rub rim or tire when released.

In Fairness to the group, anyone having trouble once we reach the Rhododendron Bridge will be asked to go back on the Overcliff Trail which is still a fun and scenic but shorter loop.

WHERE TO MEET?

West Trapps Parking Area - Mohonk Preserve

[masked],[masked]


RELATED MAPS:

New York - New Jersey Trail Conference - Shawangunk Trails Map Set

(Specifically Trail Maps 105 & 106)

Also check this link for a .pdf of Mohonk's own Bicycle Routes map

(Please Note: More routes have been opened up to biking since the publication of this .pdf)


Afterwards feel free to join us at Bacchus Restaurant, Bar & Billiards for some great food/drinks & maybe even a game of Pool! (Venue subject to change based on group preference)

Contact Information:

Bacchus Restaurant

4 South Chestnut Street

New Paltz, NY 12561

Phone: (845)[masked]

Website: http://www.bacchusnewpaltz.com/index

Hours:

Lunch: 11am – 4:30pm

Dinner: 4:30pm – 10pm

results.description:
Hi, everyone!  So excited for this meetup.

We will get together in a social but semi-structured way.  There will be soda and light snacks.  We'll spend the first 15-20 minutes just saying hello and meeting each other for the first time, welcoming any latecomers, etc.

Next, I'll lead a group discussion.  Topics will include what members of the group are looking for, what kind of anxiety people have experienced, and what they have tried to do about it in the past.  Of course, members can also bring up their own questions and topics- I am just there to organize our time and provide a little structure!

We will conclude with an open "mingle time" for everyone to follow up on things said in group discussion, talk 1-1 with anyone who seems to have similar issues, helpful ideas, etc. and then we'll wrap up the meetup!

I'm looking forward to meeting new members and greeting familiar faces!  If you can't come because of scheduling, please let us  know what days/times are best for you so we can plan more convenient times in the future.

The most important part of this meet up is the 1-1 connection you can make with others!  The group starts with an open format where we connect over  snacks and soda, followed by a group discussion, and then a "mingle" time for  everyone to connect 1-1 and build on the group discussion or talk about whatever feels most helpful for you!
results.name: NY Anxiety Meetup!

results.description:
Free swag, beer, drinks, candy & more!

Dan Lynn, CEO, AgilData
Cory Isaacson, CTO, Risk Management Solutions

RSVP at http://www.NYCSQL.com/events/222660497/

A Database Month event
http://www.DatabaseMonth.com/database/agile-data

The web app is Agile. The REST API is Agile. The testing and planning are Agile. But alas, Data infrastructures certainly are not. Once an application matures, changing the shape or indexing scheme of data often forces at best a top-down planning exercise and at worst includes schema changes which force downtime.

This talk will discuss solutions to some of the problems faced by software organizations as their products become successful and the data grows beyond the initial scope of the database, whether it starts out as relational SQL, NoSQL, or somewhere in-between.

As the user base of a software system grows, the data infrastructure is forced to evolve to meet the needs of new features, increasing the variety of data with ever larger data volumes and higher query velocity. One thing we know about evolution is that it doesn't always take the simple path or produce simple results. Data systems often grow by adding technology: a little NoSQL here, a message queue there, a Hadoop cluster hiding in the corner. This growing complexity slows down product development and challenges technology teams to ramp up entirely new skillsets reactively.

Is this your future or is this your today? Address these challenges, with a truly agile infrastructure that allows your organization to store, scale and access the data it needs.

We will cover the concept of an 'Agile data infrastructure', able to handle everything from OLTP to real-time analytics to historical reporting. A truly Agile approach allows data to be accessed as an exact match to application requirements. As application needs change, an Agile platform must be able to respond rapidly and dynamically evolve the schema, data distribution and access patterns to support high scalability with high performance - while easing the burden of the application developer and database administrators.

We will also highlight real a real-world use case from a large enterprise organization that was able to leverage an agile data approach to rapidly accelerate the pace of product development while actually simplifying operations.

We'll make you a believer in the fundamental tenants of an agile big data infrastructure, namely that it must be Simple, it must be Scaleable, it must be Streaming, and, most importantly, it must be SQL.

RSVP NOW on Meetup: http://www.NYCSQL.com/events/222660497/

Dan Lynn, CEO of AgilData, formerly CodeFutures Corporation, is an entrepreneur, technologist, teacher and technical leader with 14 years of experience in the software industry. He joins AgilData to advance the agile Big Data strategies in development around AgilData, CodeFutures' new agile Big Data platform designed to remove the complexity and limitations of current data management approaches.

Dan previously was the founding CTO at FullContact Inc., a contact management startup focusing on fuzzy match and record linkage problems. Dan is an accomplished speaker and is actively involved in the Colorado software community, serving as an organizer for the Denver Storm users group and the Boulder/Denver Big Data meet-up group. In addition, he is also a Techstars alumnus - Boulder 2011, with FullContact.

Cory Isaacson is CTO of Risk Management Solutions. As CTO, he drives the delivery of the advanced, cloud-based RMS(one) platform, leading the industry with innovative approaches to software management and advanced technology for the complex and unique challenges of risk modeling. Prior to joining RMS, Cory was CEO/CTO of CodeFutures Corporation, maker of AgilData and dbShards. Cory has founded or held executive positions in several software-related businesses, and authored the books Software Pipelines and SOA and Understanding Big Data Scalability.

He has more than 20 years of experience with advanced software architectures, and has worked with many of the world's brightest innovators in the field of high-performance computing. Cory has authored numerous articles and spoken at hundreds of public events, helping organizations address the real-world challenges of Big Data performance and scalability, and effectively applying emerging technologies to fields including social networking, mobile applications, gaming, and complex computing systems. He holds a BA from the University of California, Santa Barbara.

RSVP: http://www.NYCSQL.com/events/222660497/

Swag giveaway + junk-food/drinks at 6:30pm
Power-Networking at 6:35pm
Presentation starts at 6:40pm

You can save children from homelessness through the Techie Youth program!
Please learn how you can save the life of a child at http://www.TechieYouth.org
(saving child's life is very easy!)

RSVP Now at http://www.NYCSQL.com/events/222660497/

results.description:
At issue: how much privacy are you willing to give up for "national security"?  Is it a zero-sum game?


Two important recent developments:

I.  The federal court of appeals (2d Cir.) in ACLU v. Clapper, etal.  struck down the NSA’s mass surveillance program involving bulk collection of telephone metadata records under Section 215 of the USA PATRIOT Act.  The court held that the program "exceeds the scope of what Congress has authorized and therefore violates § 215 . . ."  The lower court's decision was vacated and remanded for further proceedings.


II.  As of June 1, 2015, parts of the USA PATRIOT Act expired.  A reform bill, known as the USA FREEDOM Act was signed into law after a last-minute showdown on the Senate Floor.


The question remains, however, whether if the reform measures adequately address the privacy concerns, while balancing the National Security concerns.


Our discussions will include:


1) the constitutional implications of the NSA surveillance program;

2) the policy ramifications of the reform measures in the FREEDOM Act;

3) the inner-workings and political dynamics on the Capitol Hill; and

4) the political context of the 2016 Presidential Elections.


---------------------------------------------------------

If it rains, we'll change the venue to an indoor location.
results.name: NSA Surveillance and the USA PATRIOT and FREEDOM Acts

It’s not, and at this meetup we’re going to showcase some of New York’s finest when it comes to tactical strategies for generating passive income. 

So many people continually fall into the trap of trading away their time for dollars (active income). Although active income is valuable, having the income to support your lifestyle allows you to do what you love, and build a business around your lifestyle, and not the other way around.

Educating Our Kids: How, What & Why?
Worried about education options for your children?

Wondering how your kids are going to learn, what they need to know, and why traditional models seem ineffective in the 21st century?

Round out your[masked] school year with a close look at education and learning in our world today. Many families are faced with daunting questions about our current educational system which was created a century ago, and the multitude of options offering solutions is just as mystifying.

Join us for discussion and an interactive workshop, based on Sir Ken Robinson’s groundbreaking analysis of our education system, exploring the big questions, critical problems, and latest ideas about how to address the learning crisis. Facilitated by The ROC’s Network for Learning and hosted by Rhonda Ross. Rhonda is a popular performing artist, parent, BIG CITY MOM OF THE WEEK award recipient, and daughter of Diana Ross who's resources allow her reach and access to the world’s best education for her son, yet she faces the same issues we do, and she is excited to work together with us as we navigate resources and explore solutions.
For more information visit www.TheROChomeschool.org

results.description:
Have you ever wondered what goes into creating an app? Do you have an idea that you would want to turn into an app? Mobile app developer and entrepreneur, David Kay will be here to give a high level overview of mobile application technology and what goes into creating a solid healthcare app. So join us for a little bit of networking and a lot of great discussions on revolutionizing health care through the use of well designed and solution meeting applications. Food and refreshments will be provided!

=======================================                                              

Presentation Topic: Healthcare App Architecture 101


Using a patient-facing app as our primary case study, we'll learn:

* How are apps made? 
* How much does development typically cost?
* How YOU can design your own app (and maybe even develop it!).
* What can apps do? What can't they do?
* What's a good use case for an app?
* What's a web app? What's a native app? When would I want to prefer one over the other?
* How can I build an app on a zero-dollar budget? And what if I had all the money in the world?
* How do I find a good programmer? How do I build a good development team? Alternatively, how do I build an app without a programmer?
* How to make smart technology decisions.
* Buy vs build?
* How to manage an app develoment project.
* What you need to know about HIPAA and FDA regulation.

You can also expect a brief intro to programmer culture, Windows vs Linux, and how your business can benefit from open source.

And, finally, we'll touch on business models for healthcare apps.


=======================================

About the Speaker:

David Kay is a on a mission to simplify medical diagnostics by wielding modern technology. He currently leads software development at SALT, a medical device startup focused on bringing hassle-free salt monitoring to patients at home. 

Happy to have been a Google engineer, and even happier to have rapidly resigned, David feels most alive when pushing his own boundaries and the stakes are high. 

He was the founding CTO at EnHatch, which provides sales and marketing technology to medical device companies, and the founding CTO of Authy, a security startup which was recently acquired by Twilio. 

David also deeply enjoys teaching, and has led mobile development workshops at Princeton University and Rutgers University, taught Ruby on Rails at iHub Nairobi, and served as an Android instructor at General Assembly. 

His technical achievements include: 

* Winner of the MIT Telehealth grand prize and the Merck Telehealth grand prize at the MIT Hacking Medicine Grand Hack 
* Winner of "best design/best prototype" at the Yale Patient Experience Hackathon 
* 3rd place at GHG Patient Outcomes Hackathon 
* 2x Global finalist at NASA Space Apps Challenge 
* 2x semi-finalist of StartupBus SxSW 
* 2nd place at TechCrunch Disrupt San Francisco 
* 2x featured for "Hack of the Month" at New York Tech Meetup 
* Led development on several pioneering iPad apps for Otsuka Medical 
* Led an 7-man team to build an app in only 3 weeks for a debut on Shark Tank 
* Project lead on the Android app for 1-800-GOT-JUNK's worldwide truck fleet 
* iPad lead for Deutsche Bank's first mobile app, GlobalPrime 

Apart from his love for medical technology, David is also an avid inline skater and certified skate instructor. 

You can reach David at: [masked]


=======================================


A big "Thank You" to our sponsor Troutman Sanders for providing the venue, refreshments, and drinks.

We look forward to seeing you there!

Come Together For Health,
HTF Organizing Team
results.name: Healthcare App Architecture 101

Dan is an accomplished speaker and is actively involved in the Colorado software community, serving as an organizer for the Denver Storm users group and the Boulder/Denver Big Data meet-up group. In addition, he is also a Techstars alumnus - Boulder 2011, with FullContact.

Cory Isaacson is CTO of Risk Management Solutions. As CTO, he drives the delivery of the advanced, cloud-based RMS(one) platform, leading the industry with innovative approaches to software management and advanced technology for the complex and unique challenges of risk modeling. Prior to joining RMS, Cory was CEO/CTO of CodeFutures Corporation, maker of AgilData and dbShards. Cory has founded or held executive positions in several software-related businesses, and authored the books Software Pipelines and SOA and Understanding Big Data Scalability.

He has more than 20 years of experience with advanced software architectures, and has worked with many of the world's brightest innovators in the field of high-performance computing. Cory has authored numerous articles and spoken at hundreds of public events, helping organizations address the real-world challenges of Big Data performance and scalability, and effectively applying emerging technologies to fields including social networking, mobile applications, gaming, and complex computing systems. He holds a BA from the University of California, Santa Barbara.

results.description:
Free swag, beer, drinks, candy & more!

Dan Lynn, CEO, AgilData
Cory Isaacson, CTO, Risk Management Solutions

RSVP at http://www.NYCSQL.com/events/222660497/

A Database Month event
http://www.DatabaseMonth.com/database/agile-data

The web app is Agile. The REST API is Agile. The testing and planning are Agile. But alas, Data infrastructures certainly are not. Once an application matures, changing the shape or indexing scheme of data often forces at best a top-down planning exercise and at worst includes schema changes which force downtime.

This talk will discuss solutions to some of the problems faced by software organizations as their products become successful and the data grows beyond the initial scope of the database, whether it starts out as relational SQL, NoSQL, or somewhere in-between.

As the user base of a software system grows, the data infrastructure is forced to evolve to meet the needs of new features, increasing the variety of data with ever larger data volumes and higher query velocity. One thing we know about evolution is that it doesn't always take the simple path or produce simple results. Data systems often grow by adding technology: a little NoSQL here, a message queue there, a Hadoop cluster hiding in the corner. This growing complexity slows down product development and challenges technology teams to ramp up entirely new skillsets reactively.

Is this your future or is this your today? Address these challenges, with a truly agile infrastructure that allows your organization to store, scale and access the data it needs.

We will cover the concept of an 'Agile data infrastructure', able to handle everything from OLTP to real-time analytics to historical reporting. A truly Agile approach allows data to be accessed as an exact match to application requirements. As application needs change, an Agile platform must be able to respond rapidly and dynamically evolve the schema, data distribution and access patterns to support high scalability with high performance - while easing the burden of the application developer and database administrators.

We will also highlight real a real-world use case from a large enterprise organization that was able to leverage an agile data approach to rapidly accelerate the pace of product development while actually simplifying operations.

We'll make you a believer in the fundamental tenants of an agile big data infrastructure, namely that it must be Simple, it must be Scaleable, it must be Streaming, and, most importantly, it must be SQL.

results.description:
Something a little different for our group and a chance to connect before summer officially kicks off. Venue is transFORM gallery located at 200 Lexington, Suite 708 (btw 32nd and 33rd)

Art Gallery Director and Curator Kara O'Neill is inviting members of The Irish / British Genealogy Group to a private viewing and reception. We will have a look at Ireland through the dreamlike eyes of the Dublin
native artist Daniel O'Sullivan. His paintings capture both the tradition and uniqueness of Irish culture found in the different towns, pubs, counties in Ireland. Even a donkey and a lad at a pub, are given tribute - (though in fairness to the truth, the donkey was seen in a field; not in a pub.)

Come share wine and light fare and listen as Daniel tells of his actual experiences behind the paintings.

Program / talk starts at 7PM.

For more info on the artist, the works and the gallery please visit www.transformgallery.com

results.description:
The Girl on the Train, by Paula  Hawkins. Rachel takes the same commuter train every morning. Every day she rattles down the track, flashes past a stretch of cozy suburban homes, and stops at the signal that allows her to daily watch the same couple breakfasting on their deck. She’s even started to feel like she knows them. “Jess and Jason,” she calls them. Their life—as she sees it—is perfect. Not unlike the life she recently lost.

And then she sees something shocking. It’s only a minute until the train moves on, but it’s enough. Now everything’s changed. Unable to keep it to herself, Rachel offers what she knows to the police, and becomes inextricably entwined in what happens next, as well as in the lives of everyone involved. Has she done more harm than good?

A compulsively readable, emotionally immersive, Hitchcockian thriller that draws comparisons to Gone Girl, The Silent Wife, or Before I Go to Sleep, this is an electrifying debut embraced by readers across markets and categories. (
results.name: The Girl on the Train, by Paula Hawkins

results.description:
This is an opportunity to practice Japanese conversation, and discuss and study the grammar, particles, Kanji, and culture. The topic varies among all these, according to what people are interested in talking about and the natural flow of conversation.

Members of all levels are welcome, from absolute beginners on up, and there is never a prerequisite. Native speakers are also encouraged to attend, both to lend their expertise and to receive the benefit of a look at the structure of Japanese from an outside linguistic perspective.

Here's a photo of the area where we meet, for reference:

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

The meeting is free, with no membership dues, hourly costs, or other expenses.

 

==> Learning & Practice RESOURCES

Various materials http://www.meetup.com/Japanese-Culture/messages/boards/thread/3199165/0#[masked]

KANJI http://www.meetup.com/Japanese-Culture/messages/boards/forum/1175397
KATAKANA http://www.meetup.com/Japanese-Culture/messages/boards/forum/1198386
HIRAGANA http://www.meetup.com/Japanese-Culture/messages/boards/forum/1198387

Please click over DISCUSSIONS ->Message Board, then select your favorite topic. Have a lot of FUN learning about Nihon & Nihongo! http://www.meetup.com/Japanese-Culture/messages/boards/
results.how_to_find_us: Look for me, with the pile of Japanese dictionaries at one of the tables in the Atrium, or one of the other groups speaking in and about Japanese.
results.name: Weekly Japanese Study Group

results.description:
We can all use a bit of extra luck when pedaling these mad NYC streets so this Thursday we will honor our Irish cycling buddy John Patterson. Be sure to tell him happy birthday!


We will meet up at our usual spot near Columbus Circle and make our way down to Battery Park to check out the Irish Hunger Memorial. We will put more miles in before ending at the Gaf West Irish Pub over in John’s childhood neighborhood aka Hell’s Kitchen.

We will do our best to stick together but please have someone’s number to call if you ride ahead and lose the group. There are a few stretches where everyone will be invited to pedal at their preferred pace and mass up points will be called out along the route…so grab your bike and bring your friends!


WHEN: Meet up at 6:30 pm, Wheels down at 7:00 pm!

MEET-UP: USS Maine National Monument, Columbus Circle

1849 Broadway, NY, NY 10023

http://goo.gl/maps/qUIEL

STOP 1: Irish Hunger Memorial

North End Ave & Vesey Street and North End Avenue

New York, NY 10280

http://bpcparks.org/whats-here/parks/irish-hunger-memorial/

END SPOT: Gaf West

401 W 48th St, New York, NY 10036

http://www.yelp.com/biz/gaf-west-new-york


ROUTE: TBA

</a>
DISTANCE: <15 Miles


Ever endeavoring to turn social cyclists into cycling commuters.
The goals are to ride bikes and hang out with friends that love riding bikes.

Feel free to contact us with any questions/concerns.
[masked]

CAUTION: If you like to ride ahead of the lead, please be sure to test the route for your own safety and for the safety of anyone that doesn't know the route and follows you. Feel free to ride ahead on bridges as we always mass up on the other side.

WHAT YOU NEED:

NYC Department of Transportation Bicycle Laws, Rules & Regulations require: White headlight and red taillight must be used from dusk to dawn, bell or other audible signal (not whistle), working brakes, and reflective tires and/or other reflective devices.

Social Cycling NYC strongly recommends that every cyclist: Follows NYC DOT rules, EXPECTS all cyclists to accept personal responsibility for their own actions (or lack thereof), and recommends cyclists bring/use bikes, helmets, locks, IDs, money for food and drinks, and cycling friends!

HOW: WE ride AS traffic and NOT AGAINST it. We stop at red lights, yield the right of way and let cars pass as best we can. We don't block intersections. We are nice to both our fellow riders and the other traffic on the road. LISTEN TO the volunteers helping to lead the ride. They are some nice people and have your best interests in mind. If you have any questions about the rules, please check here: <a href="http://www.nyc.gov/html/look/html/cyclist/cyclist_safety_text.shtml#sec6">http://www.nyc.gov/html/look/html/cyclist/cyclist_safety_text.shtml#sec6

REMINDER: The goal is to create a safe environment for all riders, but we cannot control, nor do we desire to, every rider's behavior. We promote personal responsibility and all riders are responsible for themselves. If you choose to ride with us, then you accept the risks inherent in riding a bicycle with a large group of other people riding bicycles.

Social Cycling New York City is modeled after Social Cycling Austin.https://www.facebook.com/socialcyclingaustin/info
results.how_to_find_us: Fountain at SW Corner of Central Park
results.name: TNSR - Luck of the Irish

Once an application matures, changing the shape or indexing scheme of data often forces at best a top-down planning exercise and at worst includes schema changes which force downtime.

This talk will discuss solutions to some of the problems faced by software organizations as their products become successful and the data grows beyond the initial scope of the database, whether it starts out as relational SQL, NoSQL, or somewhere in-between.

As the user base of a software system grows, the data infrastructure is forced to evolve to meet the needs of new features, increasing the variety of data with ever larger data volumes and higher query velocity. One thing we know about evolution is that it doesn't always take the simple path or produce simple results. Data systems often grow by adding technology: a little NoSQL here, a message queue there, a Hadoop cluster hiding in the corner. This growing complexity slows down product development and challenges technology teams to ramp up entirely new skillsets reactively.

Is this your future or is this your today? Address these challenges, with a truly agile infrastructure that allows your organization to store, scale and access the data it needs.

We will cover the concept of an 'Agile data infrastructure', able to handle everything from OLTP to real-time analytics to historical reporting. A truly Agile approach allows data to be accessed as an exact match to application requirements. As application needs change, an Agile platform must be able to respond rapidly and dynamically evolve the schema, data distribution and access patterns to support high scalability with high performance - while easing the burden of the application developer and database administrators.

We will also highlight real a real-world use case from a large enterprise organization that was able to leverage an agile data approach to rapidly accelerate the pace of product development while actually simplifying operations.

We'll make you a believer in the fundamental tenants of an agile big data infrastructure, namely that it must be Simple, it must be Scaleable, it must be Streaming, and, most importantly, it must be SQL.

RSVP NOW on Meetup: http://www.NYCSQL.com/events/222660497/

Dan Lynn, CEO of AgilData, formerly CodeFutures Corporation, is an entrepreneur, technologist, teacher and technical leader with 14 years of experience in the software industry. He joins AgilData to advance the agile Big Data strategies in development around AgilData, CodeFutures' new agile Big Data platform designed to remove the complexity and limitations of current data management approaches.

Dan previously was the founding CTO at FullContact Inc., a contact management startup focusing on fuzzy match and record linkage problems. Dan is an accomplished speaker and is actively involved in the Colorado software community, serving as an organizer for the Denver Storm users group and the Boulder/Denver Big Data meet-up group. In addition, he is also a Techstars alumnus - Boulder 2011, with FullContact.

Cory Isaacson is CTO of Risk Management Solutions. As CTO, he drives the delivery of the advanced, cloud-based RMS(one) platform, leading the industry with innovative approaches to software management and advanced technology for the complex and unique challenges of risk modeling. Prior to joining RMS, Cory was CEO/CTO of CodeFutures Corporation, maker of AgilData and dbShards. Cory has founded or held executive positions in several software-related businesses, and authored the books Software Pipelines and SOA and Understanding Big Data Scalability.

He has more than 20 years of experience with advanced software architectures, and has worked with many of the world's brightest innovators in the field of high-performance computing. Cory has authored numerous articles and spoken at hundreds of public events, helping organizations address the real-world challenges of Big Data performance and scalability, and effectively applying emerging technologies to fields including social networking, mobile applications, gaming, and complex computing systems. He holds a BA from the University of California, Santa Barbara.

RSVP: http://www.NYCSQL.com/events/222660497/

Power-Networking at 6:35pm
Presentation starts at 6:40pm

Please learn how you can save the life of a child at http://www.TechieYouth.org
(saving child's life is very easy!)

results.description:
Spring is here, and Thursday night runs are back!

This run starts at the "Wild Duck Pond" area of the Saddle River County Park in Ridgewood. We will start at the beginning of the mile markers which is near the exit, not near the entrance. There's parking close to the beginning of the path. If you cannot park in the lot nearest the beginning of the path, you'll need to reenter the park and park in the next closest lot. The driving area of the park is U-shaped so to get to the parking lot closest to the start of the run, you essentially drive around the "U" and approach the exit to the last lot on the right (by the dog park).

We will start at the "Wild Duck Pond Area" and will turn around at some point. If you'd like to run additional miles, you are certainly more than welcome to do so as the mile markers make it simple to track your distance. Depending on the turnout we sometimes break off into little groups of two or three people, each of which may go at slightly different paces and/or distances. Regardless, if you wish to run at a slower pace, I am more than happy to run with you at your preferred pace. Nobody gets left in the dust. This is a fun run, not a competition.

For those who wish to stick around after the run, we may get together at (insert favorite Ridgewood hot spot here) to relax, catch up, and share some laughs. When we do this, we usually get to the restaurant between 7:30 and 7:45. If anyone cares to join us that didn't come to the run, you are certainly welcome.

We will run rain or shine, hot or cold. If you RSVP "Yes", please do your best to be on time as we'll only wait a couple of minutes past 6:30 PM to get rolling. If you have questions, comments, or doubts, feel free to email me. Looking forward to seeing you on Thursday.
results.name: 4 Mile Run in Ridgewood (Wild Duck Pond)

Our Pairs Trading Strategy speaker has fallen ill and will not be able to present at tonight's meetup. Not to fear! We have lined up another great talk for you. Details below:

The power of news & blog data integrated into automated strategies 

​A new era has begun and Quants can now harness the power of big data analytics. 

We are in a world where massive amounts of contents from the web are being extracted and analyzed in real-time to create useful analytics solely for automated strategies. These analytics can be used to detect trading signals and improve risk management and returns for your portfolio.

Accern uses data science to deliver a real-time data feed filled with actionable media analytics derived from articles across 20 million news and blog sources. Powered by algorithmic trading platforms like Quantopian, this data feed can seamlessly be integrated into any automated strategies you desire to generate alpha. 

​We will briefly introduce and discuss a Market Neutral, Trend-Follow, and Event Driven strategy that was conducted via Quantopian platform​. We will also discuss how the algorithm was constructed, how it works, and how you can potentially apply it to live trading via Quantopian. 

Quantopian will host this meetup at CQF Fitch Learning at 55 Broad Street. Stop by, have some pizza, meet with other members in the group, and learn more about different data sources to generate alpha. 

Pizza and beer will be provided by Quantopian.

We will hold the Pairs Trading Strategy talk at a later date.  Stay tuned!

Do not register here at Meetup.


Java 8 in Anger - @trisha_gee

Java 9 is just around the corner, and yet many of us developers have yet to use Java 8 features in an application. The goal of this presentation is to move beyond slide-sized examples of streams and lambdas, and to show how to build a fully working end-to-end application using just the core libraries available in the latest version of Java.

In this session, Trisha will build a Java 8 application live. This application will consume a real-time feed of high velocity data, contain services that make sense of the data, and present it in a JavaFX dashboard. Along the way, we’ll encounter Java 8 streams, lambdas, new ways of working with collections, and probably bump into the new date and time API.

Building Microservices in Java - @crichardson

In this talk you will learn about a modern way of designing applications that’s very different from the traditional approach of building monolithic applications.We will talk about what microservices are, its architecture, it’s benefits and drawbacks. We will describe event sourcing and how it’s an extremely useful persistence mechanism for persisting functional domain objects in a microservices architecture.

Chris Richardson is a developer and architect. He is a Java Champion, a JavaOne rock star and the author of POJOs in Action, which describes how to build enterprise Java applications with POJOs and frameworks such as Spring and Hibernate. Chris is also the founder of the original CloudFoundry.com, an early Java PaaS for Amazon EC2. He consults with organizations to improve how they develop and deploy applications.

Limited seating.  Please only RSVP if you are definitely coming. 

SUBWAY LINES

4, 5  Borough Hall  2 blocks away

ABOUT BEN PARR

Ben Parr is an award-winning journalist, author, entrepreneur, investor and expert on attention. Through his unique experience as a leading technology writer, venture capitalist and prolific public speaker, Parr has coached dozens of young startups and Fortune 500 corporations on how to get attention for their products. He was named one of the top ten tech journalists in the world by Say Media and named to the Forbes “30 Under 30.” Parr is Co-Founder and Managing Partner of Parrticipation, a consultancy that works with later-stage companies and Fortune 500s on how to capture attention for their launches and marketing campaigns. He is also a columnist for Inc. Magazine and a contributor to CNBC, and Bloomberg. Previously, Parr was the Co-Editor and Editor-at-Large of Mashable, where he wrote more than 2,400 articles on social media and technology, managed Mashable’s editorial team, and interviewed everyone from Ashton Kutcher to Mark Zuckerberg. He also served as Columnist and Commentator for CNET. Parr’s work has been featured in a variety of media, including CNBC, CNN, Fox News, The Wall Street Journal, NPR and The New York Times.

results.description:
On the 20th anniversary of its original release, The FBI's War on Black America is being made available on DVD for the first time. Co-produced/Co-directed by Deb Ellis and Denis Meuller (directors of Howard Zinn: You Can't Be Neutral on a Moving Train), The FBI's War on Black America looks at a dark period in our country's history. The film is a documentary exploration of the lives and deaths of people targeted by the US government's COINTELPRO program, an FBI launched program aimed against organized efforts by African-Americans to gain rights guaranteed by our constitution. Includes both archival footage and contemporary interviews with people involved in the movement.

The FBI's War on Black America offers a thought provoking look at a government-sanctioned conspiracy, the FBI's counter intelligence program known as Cointelpro. This documentary establishes historical perspective on the measures initiated by J. Edgar Hoover and the FBI which aimed to discredit black political figures and forces of the late 1960's and early 1970's.
results.name: $10 Movie Night: The FBI's War on Black America (includes popcorn and drink)

results.description:
For all the Noise, do Shareholder Activists create Shareholder Value?

 
Both the profile of shareholder activists as well as the investments into activists funds have drastically increased over the past years.  Additionally some of the more traditional investment funds have started to play a more activists role towards the companies they are invested in.

Many activist shareholders claim that, in an investment world where a larger percentage of the money is put into passive funds and ETFs  than ever before and small discrepancies get arbitraged out by high frequency traders, they are the guardians of a more efficient market while keeping pressure on boards and managers to deliver shareholder value. The boards and managers under attack often fire back stating that the activist shareholder is only, like the corporate raiders of the 80s, interested in a quick buck by leaving the company in worse shape upon sale of the investment.

In this session we will discuss activist shareholders, what they are, how they operate and if indeed they are creating better companies while making their investors richer.

The session speaker is Jan Simon, Assistant Professor of  Financial Management at IESE Business School. The session will be followed by a networking cocktail.
results.name: Shareholder engagement, what is the big deal?
